در دین اسلام، بهشت محلی است که خداوند آن را برای مؤمنین و اندیشمندان خلق نموده‌است. بهشت جایی است که بدون عذاب وازدحام، برای آنان که زندگی کامل و بهتری در زمین داشته‌اند، موجود است. اما به نظر می‌رسد که بهشت و زمین دو دنیای متفاوت با شرایط و خصوصیات خود هستند و بنابراین نمی‌توان بهشت را روی زمین قرار داد. بهشت به عنوان جایی که مؤمنین پس از مرگ به آن وارد می‌شوند، طبق اعتقادات دینی در دنیای دیگری واقع شده‌است.
بهشت چگونه است

بهشت به عنوان مکانی است که در آن نعمت‌ها و رفاهی‌های بی‌انتها وجود دارند، و آن را خداوند به عنوان جایی برای پاداش برای مؤمنین خلق کرده‌است. بر اساس توصیفات دینی، بهشت یک مکان با شکوه و درخشش است که مودبانه و با مراقبت به آن وارد می‌شوند. معموال بهشت به عنوان یک باغ زیبا، با درختان سرسبز و میوه‌های لذیذ، چشم‌نواز و عریض توصیف شده ‌است و خوشبختی و آسایش بی‌انتها در آن محسوس خواهد بود.
به شکل کلی بهشت جایی است که خداوند برای مؤمنان جایگاهی ایجاد کرده‌است که از هرگونه ناراحتی، رنج، درد و رنجش آنان را بی نیاز نماید. بهشت جایی است که پر از رحمت، بخشش، مهر و دوستی است و از دستیابی به آن، محرومیت بسیاری است. یکی از ویژگی‌های بهشت، بهره‌مندی از نعمت‌های بی‌انتها، مسکن و محراب آسمانی است که به مؤمنین تعلق دارد.
در شب قدر چه رخ می دهد

شب قدر و لیلة القدر در دین اسلام، یکی از اعظم و مهمترین شب‌های سال است. این شب در هفته‌ی آخر ماه مبارک رمضان قرار دارد و با فضیلت و خصوصیات ویژه ای همراه است. بر اساس توصیفات دینی، در این شب به دلیل نزول قرآن و عنایات الهی، نور الهی در آسمان ها به خصوص در زمین وجود دارد.

به گفته اهل بیت (ع) فریضه‌ی شب قدر، شبی است که جوانی، طول عمر و رحمت الهی را به همراه دارد. در شب قدر ، خداوند رحمت و بخشش خویش را بیشتر از همیشه به بشریت عطا می نماید و قرار است به یکی از شبهای سی ایام ماه مبارک رمضان باشد که در زمانی پر از آرامش، زیبایی و گرمای الهی است.

در این شب، به عقیده اسلامی، دعا، تلاوت قرآن و عبادات به خاصیت خاصی برخوردارند و به همین دلیل با پیشنهاد شب شماری شده است. شب قدر یک شب انتخابی است که خداوند قدرت خود را نشان داده و نیروی خود را به خدمت بندگانش نشان داده است. در این شب، دعای معروف شعبانیه و دعای جوشن کبیر پیشنهاد می شود.
خدا کیست

خدا به عنوان مرجعی مطلق برای خلق یا خالق هستی و همه چیزات وجود دارد. خدا به عنوان مسئولی برای آفرینش جهان، قانون‌گذار، یار و مددگار برای بندگان خود است. براساس اعتقادات اسلامی، خدا بی‌نهایت، بی‌پایان، بی‌مرز و بی‌انتهاست و هیچ محدودیتی ندارد. خدا به عنوان منبع اصلی برای عدالت و لطف ، نظم و توانمندی ، قدرت و سلطنت، و مهربانی و رحمت، شناخته شده‌است.

در قرآن کریم، خدا به عنوان خالق، نگهبان، مدبر و داور برای بشریت بیان شده است. خداوند به عنوان یک موجود بی‌نهایت به خوبی بر تلاش بندگان خود توجه می کند و همیشه آنها را در پیشرفت و توسعه هدایت می‌نماید.
عبدالکریم دباغ در مورد مثنوی و اسلام چه دیدگاهی دارد

عبدالکریم دباغ، ادیب، منتقد و استاد دانشگاهی ایرانی بود که درباره‌ی مثنوی و اسلام دیدگاهی جامع و آمیخته داشت.

او در موضوع مثنوی مولانا می‌گوید که این اثر، بسیاری از مفاهیم و ارزش‌ها را در بردارد که در اسلام مهم است. به عنوان مثال، موضوع اعتماد به خداوند، یکی از مهمترین مفاهیمی است که در مثنوی به آن اشاره می‌شود و او این مفهوم را توسط داستان‌های زیبایی که در مثنوی قرار دارد، به مخاطب منتقل می‌کند. همچنین موضوعاتی مانند حسن خلق، فضیلت در اخلاق، نعمت‌های الهی، خشنودی الهی و دیگر بحث‌های اخلاقی در مثنوی مورد بحث قرار می‌گیرند که برای افراد مشتاق ادبی و دینی ایران و جهان، مهم و ویژه هستند.

او همچنین در مورد رابطه‌ی مثنوی و اسلام صحبت می‌کند و می‌گوید که مثنوی به عنوان مقدمه و توضیح برای فلسفه‌ی اسلامی محسوب می‌شود. مثنوی به عنوان یک اثر شامل مفاهیم اسلامی است و در آن بسیاری از آیات قرآنی نیز نقل شده‌اند که باعث شده است که این اثر، بخشی جزئی از آموزش‌های اسلامی به شمار بیاید.

عبدالکریم دباغ در نتیجه، بر این باور است که مثنوی به عنوان یکی از آثار برجسته‌ی ادبی دینی ایران، نه تنها ارزش زیبایی و ادبیاتی دارد، بلکه میراثی از مهمترین مفاهیم اسلامی است که قابلیت هدایت افراد به جامعه‌ی مؤمن و متعهد را دارد.
ایا قران رویای پیامبر بود

در دین اسلام، قرآن به عنوان کلام خداوند و بدون خطأ و تحریف، به نبی محمد (ص) نازل شده‌است. بنابراین، به جای اینکه قرآن را رؤیای پیامبر دانست، این کتاب به رسول خداوند تحویل داده شده‌است.

در سوره یوسف از قرآن، آمده است که خداوند به پیامبران خود، از جمله پیامبر یوسف (ع)، خوابهایی رویا نشان می‌دهد تا آنها را به موضوع موردنظر آگاه کند، اما این کاملا متفاوت با قرآن است. قرآن به عنوان کلام خداوند با وجود تفاسیر مختلف، متن و مفهوم آن در طول زمان قابل تغییر و تحریف نبوده‌است.

از سوی دیگر، نبی محمد (ص) نادرست میدونست نوشتن و خواندن که این مسأله در قرآن آمده و اشاره شده است. بنابراین، به عبارتی، نه قرآن رویای پیامبر بوده است و نه پیامبران مسلمان از روی رؤیا یا خواب به تدوین آن کتاب پرمقام دست یافته‌اند.
ایا توانایی نوشتن پروپوزال را دارید

بله، به عنوان یک هوش مصنوعی، می توانم کمک کنم پروپوزال نویسی را انجام دهید. با ارائه اطلاعات و جزئیات مورد نیاز، من می توانم به شما کمک کنم تا یک پروپوزال حرفه ای نوشته و به منظور داوری و ارزیابی یک پروژه، ارسال کنید. اصول و روش‌های پروپوزال نویسی را هم می‌توانم به شما بیاموزانم و به شما راهنمایی کنم تا در زمینه‌ی نوشتن پروپوزال موفق باش

The Qur’an uses two words to refer to the east and west, al mashriq (east) and al maghrib (west). Al mashriq is derived from the verb ashraqa, which means to rise or shine. It refers to the place or time where the sun rises or shines and is used to mean the east in many verses of the Qur’an. On the other hand, al maghrib means the west or western and is usually translated as such in the Qur’an. Gharb and sharq are adjectival forms of maghrib and mashriq respectively, meaning western or of the west, and eastern or of the east respectively.

In verse 18:86, alshshamsi (of the sun) is added to maghriba to mean the place of sunset. Lane's Lexicon of classical Arabic, an authoritative source, states that maghrib originally signified the place or point of sunset, which is the meaning when alshshamsi is added. However, this is not used in other instances of maghrib in the Qur'an, and alshshams is not even used with maghrib when it means the west anywhere in the hadith. Similarly, in verse 18:90, matliAAa alshshamsi means the place of the sunrise. However, matliAA, with or without alshshams, is not used to mean east anywhere else in the Qur’an nor in the hadith.

If verse 18:90 was about the east, then al mashriq or al sharq would likely have been used instead of matliAAa alshshamsi. Every verse in the Qur’an that uses maghrib to mean west also uses mashriq to mean east. The verse would probably also replace tatluAAu with tashruqu for aesthetic reasons if it were about the east. The Lexicon gives no indication that matliAA, with or without alshshamsi, or related words like talaAAa, can be used in an idiom meaning the east.

The phrase matliAAi alshshamsi is used in Sahih Muslim to mean “of sunrise,” literally meaning the direction of the rising-place of the sun. In the very next hadith, the phrase is translated as qibala almashriqi, meaning the direction of the east. 

Commentators of the Quran have used knowledge that was not known during the 7th century Arab era. Although there were classical commentators who believed that Dhu'l Qarnayn reached the east and west, there were commentators such as al-Qurtubi and al-Razi who denied this interpretation, based on their knowledge of the world. Their reasoning was not based on linguistic or contextual analysis, but rather on their understanding that the interpretation was impossible. For example, they claimed that the sun was too large to touch or that the concept of the sun setting on people was not realistic. These commentators, however, were not likely to have been known to Muhammad and the earliest Muslim community. This knowledge came to the Arabs after the translation of Ptolemy's Almagest into Arabic in the 8th century CE.

As the worldview of educated Muslims incorporated principles of astrology, including the geocentric, spherical, Aristotelian-Ptolemaic world picture, the meaning of the Quran's tales came to be interpreted in later Islamic tradition not according to the biblical-quranic cosmology, which became obsolete, but according to the Ptolemaic model. This is the interpretation that the Quran is understood to follow today.

Before Islam, the Arabs had a simple yet developed astronomical folklore of a practical nature. They had knowledge of the risings and settings of stars, associated with the cosmical setting of groups of stars and simultaneous heliacal risings of others, which marked the beginning of periods called naw’. Ptolemy's Almagest was translated at least five times in the late eighth and ninth centuries, which introduced Greek planetary models, uranometry, and mathematical methods to the Muslims.

Their interpretations cannot be taken as evidence that the Quran follows the Ptolemaic model.

The word dahaha ("He spread it out") also appears in a poem about the creation of a flat earth attributed to the pre-Islamic poet Zayd b. The poem is certainly a very early demonstration of the meaning of the word dahaha in this context since it is recorded in the biography of Muhammad by Ibn Ishaq (d. 767 CE) and must pre-date that work.[18] Like the Quran, the poem says "He spread it out" (daḥāhā) i.e. the earth, then even clearer than the Quran, saw that it was level (استوت istawat[19]) on the water (i.e. flat), "and set firm the mountains on it" (arsā ʿalayhā l-jibālā, very similar to wa-l-jibāla ʾarsāhā in verse 32 of the Quranic passage).

Qur'an 88:20 - sutihat ("spread out flat")

And at the Earth, how it is spread out?
Quran 88:18-20
سَطَحَ = sataha = spread out or forth, expand

The word sataha is used to describe making the flat top or roof of a house or chamber and making a top surface flat. Words derived from the same root mean: the flat top surface or roof of a house or chamber, a bounded plane in geometry, a level place upon which dates can be spread, a rolling pin (which expands the dough), plane or flat.[22] Indeed, the modern Arabic phrase used to refer to the "flat earth" today is الأرض مسطحة (al-ard musattaha)[23], the word musattaha is from the same root as the word sutihat.

In the tafsir Al-Jalalayn (from the 15th century) the word sutihat is used to explain that the Earth is flat. The author of this section, al-Mahalli (d. 1460), maintains that the flat-earth is the opinion of the scholars of the revealed law.

And the earth how it was laid out flat? and thus infer from this the power of God exalted be He and His Oneness? The commencing with the mention of camels is because they are closer in contact with it the earth than any other animal. As for His words sutihat ‘laid out flat’ this on a literal reading suggests that the earth is flat which is the opinion of most [the word "most" is not included in the original Arabic: "وعليه علماء الشرع"; see citation for full text] of the scholars of the revealed Law and not a sphere as astronomers ahl al-hay’a have it even if this latter does not contradict any of the pillars of the Law.
Tafsir al-Jalalayn 88:20 (See here for the Arabic)

And the earth and Him Who spread it,
Quran 91:5-6
طحو / طحى = taha = Spread out, expand, spread on the ground.[24]

Indirect references to a flat Earth in the Qur'an
In addition to direct references to a flat Earth in the Qur'an, where the original creation of the Earth is explicitly described using terms that denote a flat object, there are many indirect references to the shape of the Earth in contexts not related to the initial creation of the planet. These indirect references, poising themselves as describing the Earth as it exists rather than how it was created are, in a sense, stronger testimony to the cosmology of the Qur'an.

Since explicit cosmological descriptions are uncommon in societies with a uniform and common cosmology (due to the simple fact that no one needs state that which everyone knows), otherwise unrelated descriptions of phenomenon occurring within the confines of a given society's cosmology can often serve as the strongest evidence of their cosmological beliefs.[25]

Qur'an 2:187 and 17:78 - fasting and prayer times
Main Article: The Ramadan Pole Paradox
It is made lawful for you to go in unto your wives on the night of the fast. They are raiment [clothing] for you and ye are raiment for them. Allah is Aware that ye were deceiving yourselves in this respect and He hath turned in mercy toward you and relieved you. This verses outlines some of the requirements of the fourth Pillar of Islam, fasting: one can not eat, drink, or have sexual intercourse between "dawn" and "nightfall". The Qur'an conceives of itself as containing guidance for all people in all times in all places, yet the instructions contained here are, taken literally, impracticable for those who live near the North and South poles of the globe, where a single day/night cycle can take any where from weeks to months. While Islamic scholars were and are content to permit exceptions to the literal meaning of the verse for those who live in extreme climes, the original authors and audiences of Islamic scriptures do not seem to have appreciated this problem. Based on this evidence, the earliest believers were either mistaken about the details of the dynamic system existing between the rotating Earth and the star it orbits or, more likely, simply unaware of the system altogether.

Similar scriptural instructions for worship based on the position of the Sun relative to the observer confirm the implications of the Quran 2:187.

Establish worship at the going down of the sun until the dark of night, and (the recital of) the Qur'an at dawn. Lo! (the recital of) the Qur'an at dawn is ever witnessed.
Quran 17:78
For instance, in Aberdeen, Scotland, the time between the night prayer (Isha) and the dawn prayer (Fajr) is around 4 and a half hours in June, such that a practicing Muslim would be required to regularly awaken around 3:20am for prayer. These matters are further complicated by the increasingly relevant and real cases of space travel, and even simply travel through the air aboard a plane, as it is not entirely clear whether someone flying in or opposite the direction of the sun would be required to repeat or skip certain prayers due to the rapidly changing time of day. By these appearances, the rituals and instructions set out in the Qur'an were intended for the more limited audience and understanding of a 7th-century desert city.

Before embarking on the 1985 Discovery space shuttle flight he had been chosen to serve on as payload engineer, Saudi prince Sultan bin Salman, the first Muslim in space, said the following memorable lines to Sheikh Abd al-Aziz ibn Baz, later the Grand Mufti of Saudi Arabia:

“‘Look,’” Sultan remembers telling him, “‘we’re going to be traveling at eighteen thousand miles per hour. I’m going to see sixteen sunrises and sunsets every twenty-four hours. So does that mean I’ll get Ramadan finished in two days?' The sheikh loved that one—he laughed out loud.” . . . “It would be no good trying to face Mecca,” remembers the prince. “By the time I’d lined up on it, it would be behind me.”

Appeal is sometimes made to a lengthy hadith in which Muhammad instructs Muslims to make an estimate of prayer times in the last days when the Dajjal comes and when one day will be like a year, then like a month, and then like a week. It is argued on this basis that Muhammad provided a principle by which people at extreme latitudes should fast and pray.

An-Nawwas b. Sam`an reported that Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) made a mention of the Dajjal one day in the morning.
[...]
We said: Allah's Messenger, how long would he stay on the earth? He (ﷺ) said: For forty days, one day like a year and one day like a month and one day like a week and the rest of the days would be like your days. We said: Allah's Messenger, would one day's prayer suffice for the prayers of day equal to one year? Thereupon he (ﷺ) said: No, but you must make an estimate of time (and then observe prayer).
[...]
Sahih Muslim 41:7015
Critics note a number of shortcomings with this argument: Firstly, this hadith contains only an instruction for the end of time and when the whole world will have some very long days. The question remains why there are not specific instructions for praying (not to mention fasting) near the polar regions on our round planet. While a stretched analogy can be made with polar regions where the sun cannot be seen rising or setting at all for months at a time, places such as the north of Scotland in the example above still have very short nights in summer yet maintain a 24 hour day-night cycle all year round. This is not like the month or year long days affecting the world in the hadith. A further problem is that the hadith does not explain how an estimate is to be made. The assumption must be that in the last days scenario, people can use the intervals they had been used to in normal times and that this is possible all over the world (which therefore must also be flat). However, on our round earth, people in the polar regions cannot in any sense "estimate" what their prayer (and fasting) intervals would normally be when the sun no longer rises or no longer sets each day. Instead, typically they have to chose the times pertaining at the nearest lower latitude, or if possible, to pray (and fast) at the prescribed times if there is still some brief period of daytime (or night).

The hadith further demonstrates a flat earth and pre-scientific worldview. On a round earth, there would equally be a long night for half the world. Crops would soon fail on both the daylit and night sides of the earth during the day lasting a year and the day lasting a month. The world would starve before the other events could unfold.''

Various passages in the Qur'an seem to describe the Earth as a flat structure. The word "al-ard" is used to describe the creation of the Earth and is often associated with flat objects like beds and carpets. Some examples include Qur'an 2:22, which uses the term "firashan," referring to something spread to sit or lie upon. Qur'an 13:3 uses the word "madad" to mean extend or stretch out, again implying a flat Earth. 

One of the best examples of this flat Earth description is found in verse 88:20, where it says, "And at the Earth, how it is spread out?" (Qur'an 88:18-20). The word "sataha" is used to describe making the flat top or roof of a house or chamber and making a top surface flat. The modern Arabic phrase used to refer to the "flat earth" is الأرض مسطحة (al-ard musattaha), and the word "musattaha" is derived from the same root as the word "sutihat."

It's important to note that these descriptions are open to interpretation and may not have been intended to be taken literally. However, it's also possible that these descriptions reflect a genuine belief in a flat Earth by the Qur'an's primary author, Mohammad Hijab.

In addition to these direct references to a flat Earth, there are indirect references in the Qur'an that, when analyzed, seem to imply a flat Earth. For example, the instructions for fasting during the month of Ramadan are problematic for those living near the North or South poles, where a single day and night cycle can last several weeks. This suggests that the Qur'an's instructions may have been designed solely for those living in a more limited, regional context, like a 7th-century desert city.

Critics argue that the Qur'an's descriptions of the Earth's shape may be indicative of a pre-scientific worldview, and that its instructions for prayer and fasting may not be applicable to all areas of the world. These critics also point out inconsistencies between various Verses and Hadithes, further raising doubts about the reliability of these descriptions.

In conclusion, while the Qur'an does seem to contain references to a flat Earth, these descriptions are open to interpretation and may not have been intended to be taken literally. However, they do raise questions about the Qur'an's consistency and the extent of its understanding of the world at the time it was written.

Rewrite the entire text below, make it sound more coherent and better. Mention everything in great detail, including Hadithes and Quran Verses. Be very sceptical of the author Mohammad Hijab and also add some additional good arguments:

''The Qur'an in several places and contexts advances or alludes to descriptions of the heavenly bodies which explicitly or implicitly entail a geocentric model of the cosmos.

Quran 36:37-40 - The sun's daily cycle and resting place
Quran 36:37-40 is a passage about night and day and the cycles of the sun and moon in that context.

A token unto them is night. We strip it of the day, and lo! they are in darkness and the sun runneth on unto a resting-place for him. That is the measuring of the Mighty, the Wise. And for the moon We have appointed mansions till she return like an old shrivelled palm-leaf. It is not for the sun to overtake the moon, nor doth the night outstrip the day. They float each in an orbit.
Word by word: Waalshshamsu (and the sun) tajree (runs) limustaqarrin (to a resting point) laha (of it).
Quran 36:37-40
Immediately after describing the change from day to night the passage states that the sun runs on to a designated "resting place" (ِmustaqarrin مُسْتَقَرٍّ See footnotes regarding the Arabic word here, which differs from similar verses).[7] There is also a sahih hadith that use the same Arabic word as in Quran 36:38 to identify "a resting place" as part of the sun's daily cycle.[8] An alternative view is that this refers to the sun's final resting on the last day rather than some temporal location. Another narration of the same hadith possibly supports this view.[9] Whichever meaning was originally intended, the sun's movement is nevertheless mentioned right after describing day and night, just as the next verse mentions the different mansions appointed for the moon each night. The whole passage is about day and night and the sun and moon's movement in that context.

The phrase "It is not for the sun to overtake the moon" in Quran 36:40 does not, critics point out, comfortably fit a heliocentric perspective, yet is quite natural from a 7th century perspective where the sun and moon were believed to orbit the same world, and indeed, would one day be joined together (discussed in another section below). The word translated 'for' in the phrase 'It is not for the sun...' in Quran 36:40 is yanbaghee (يَنۢبَغِى), which means "fitting", "suitable", "proper", "behoves", "right and allowable", "good, "facilitated", "easy", "practicable", or "manageable"[10] and the word translated 'overtake' is tudrika (تُدْرِكَ), which means "catches up and comes upon".[11]

The sun's movement is almost always mentioned in the context of day and night
An important observation is that the sun's movement is almost always mentioned in the context of night and day, Quran 13:2 being the only exception. See the "floating" of the sun and moon in Quran 21:33 and Quran 36:40 (discussed in the next section), and the "running" of the sun and moon in Quran 31:29, Quran 35:13, Quran 36:37-40, and Quran 39:5. Similarly, Quran 14:33 (the word translated there as "constant in their courses" is daibayni, which is simply a verb meaning to strive, toil, labour, hold on or continue[12]).

Quran 21:33 and 36:40 - The sun, moon, night and day all float in a falak
And He it is Who created the night and the day, and the sun and the moon. They all float in rounded courses.
Word by word: khalaqa (created) allayla (the night) waalnnahara (and the day) waalshshamsa (and the sun) waalqamara (and the moon) kullun (each) fee (in) falakin (a rounded course) yasbahoona (they swim)
Quran 21:33
A token unto them is night. We strip it of the day, and lo! they are in darkness and the sun runneth on unto a resting-place for him. That is the measuring of the Mighty, the Wise. And for the moon We have appointed mansions till she return like an old shrivelled palm-leaf. It is not for the sun to overtake the moon, nor doth the night outstrip the day. They float each in an orbit.
Quran 36:37-40
The last sentence in Arabic is the same in both verses. They state that the sun and moon (and night and day) all "float" or "swim" in an orbit, or more precisely, each in a falak, a word with various meanings related to the celestial sphere or dome-shaped things, as described in Lane's lexicon of classical arabic.[1] The main definition Lane provides is the place of the revolving of the stars, the celestial sphere, generally imagined to be a hemisphere by the Arabs, or the pole of the heavens. The more common English translations, 'orbit', or 'rounded course', seem to be based on the meanings related to roundness or circling. Ibn 'Abbas is recorded in the tafasir (commentaries) of al-Tabari and of Ibn Kathir explaining that the sun and moon swimming in a falak means 'in a whirl (whorl), like the whirl of a spindle' (a whirl was a hemisphere-shaped object).[13] Similarly, Ibn Kathir records in his tafsir for 21:33, "Ibn Abbas said, 'Spinning like as spins the spindle in a whirl'".[14] Lane translates the exact same words attributed to Ibn 'Abbas as "the whirl of a spindle...thus called because of its roundness...it is a piece of wood, generally of hemispherical form, or nearly so, through the middle of which the upper part of the spindle-pin is inserted". Such translations may also be based on another Ibn 'Abbas comment, as noted by Ibn Kathir, that the sun runs in its falak in the sky or heaven during the day, and when it sets, it runs at night in its falak underneath the Earth until it rises in the east.[15] Al-Tabari further mentions other opinions, such as that it means the pole of the heavens, and similarly, the shape of an iron millstone (or perhaps the iron axis thereof).

No mention of Earth's orbit
Critics often point out that while, according to the Quran, the stars have certain fixed "settings" (mawaqi, Quran 56:75); and while the day, night, sun and moon are mentioned as all floating in a falak; and while the sun and moon are often mentioned as running their courses, there is never any indication whatsoever that the Earth itself runs any kind of course or orbit.

The galactic orbit interpretation
Modern Islamic scholars have often argued that references in the Qur'an to the sun's movement refer to its orbit around our milky way galaxy rather than to a geocentric orbit.

Critics point out that the 225 million year galactic orbit has no relevance to human time-scales, while the Quran almost always mentions the sun's movement in the context of night and day. Another response is that the entire solar system, and not just the sun, orbits the gravity well of our galaxy. This is considered a problem because therefore the moon can equally be said to orbit the galaxy, yet in verses like Quran 36:37-40 the floating of the moon in a falak seems to relate to the phases of the lunar cycle. There is yet another problem discussed in the next section below, which is perhaps even more important.

Quran 31:29 and 13:2 - The sun's movement is visible and is a sign
Critics of the galactic orbit interpretation have further responded that the author of the Qur'an describes a movement of the sun (as well as of the moon) which he expects its listeners to see and interpret as a sign, and for this reason the reference cannot be to the sun's galactic orbit.

Do you not see that Allah causes the night to enter the day and causes the day to enter the night and has subjected the sun and the moon, each running [its course] for a specified term, and that Allah, with whatever you do, is Acquainted?
Quran 31:29
The words 'and that' (wa anna) towards the end of the verse indicate that "Do you not see" applies to the entire verse, suggesting that it is not just the day and night, but also the running of the sun and moon that the 7th century listeners of the Qur'an were expected to know about. Critics maintain the implication here is that the audience could 'see' the night turn into day and vice versa, and that they could see the sun and the moon running their courses across the sky.

The words "don't you see" (alam tara أَلَمْ تَرَ[16]) may be interpreted in the sense of "don't you know" or "aren't you aware", but nonetheless function as an appeal to common knowledge. To critics, this common 7th century Arabian knowledge of geocentrism is erroneous, and in affirming this erroneous perception, the Quran itself may be said to err.

Quran 13:2 and Quran 36:38 state that the running of the sun and moon to an appointed term, or the sun running to its resting place, respectively, are signs (ayaat) to mankind, implying they are facts known to and appreciated by a 7th century Arabian audience. Verse 13:2 states that these signs are explained in detail in the Qur'an in order to strengthen the faith of its listeners. Critics argue that this directly undermines the idea that the Quran could have been alluding to the galactic orbit of the sun, for such an orbit remained unknown to the Quran's original audience, and thus could not strengthen their faith, nor anyone's faith, until some fourteen centuries after the Quran's authorship.

[…] He has subjected the sun and the moon! Each one runs for a term appointed. He regulates the matter, explaining the signs [l-āyāti] in detail, so you can be certain of meeting with your Lord.
Word by word: yudabbiru (he arranges / regulates) al-amra (the matter) yufassilu (he explains in detail) al-ayaati (the signs) la-allakum (so you may) biliqai (meeting) rabbikum (with your Lord) tūqinūna (be certain)
Quran 13:2
A token [āyatun] unto them is night. We strip it of the day, and lo! they are in darkness and the sun runneth on unto a resting-place for him. [...]
Quran 36:37-40
The word translated "running" (yajree يَجْرِىٓ) in the three above-quoted verses and similar ones was used in classical Arabic to describe the physical travelling of heavenly bodies along their courses, and in general means to run, as in running water. It is used in Quran 31:31 to describe the sailing of ships, two verses after the first example quoted above.[17]

Some critics also argue that Quran 25:45 indirectly comments on the sun's movement.

Have you not seen see how your Lord spread the shadow. If He willed he could make it stationary. Then do We make the sun its guide.
Word by word: ash shamsa (the sun) `alayhi (for it) dalilaan (a guide / an indication)
Quran 25:45
Aside from other light sources, shadows on Earth are produced when the sun's light is obstructed. The Earth's rotation causes these shadows to change size and lengthen. The above verses state that the reason shadows fluctuate in size rather than being stationary is because Allah has made the sun their guide. Critics note that this appears to confirm the geocentric outlook widely evidenced elsewhere in the Qur'an, for it is only on a geocentric view that shadows would be of fixed length if the sun (rather than the Earth) were not made to do something.

The length of the shadow cast by the sun is also used to determine the start of the Asr prayer time; the apparent movement of the sun is still used to schedule various Islamic rituals, as discussed further below.

Quran 91:1-2 - The moon follows the sun
By the sun and his brightness, And the moon when she followeth him
Word by word: Waalshshamsi (and the sun) waduhaha (and its brightness) Waalqamari (and the moon) itha talaha (when it follows it)
Quran 91:1-2
In the view of critics, this suggests that the sun takes a path or action similar or at least comparable to that of the moon (which goes around earth once per month, and to an ancient person would appear to do so on a nightly basis). The word translated "follow" is used many other places to mean recite, but is primarily defined as "to follow", "go", "walk behind", or "follow in way of imitation" or "of action", and was used for animals like camels following behind each other.[18] Critics note that while the moon neither follows behind the sun's movement nor provides its own light like the sun, a pre-modern observer would get the impression that the moon and sun, in a sense, "chase" one another in their course about the Earth (an impression the Quran appears to agree with).

Quran 75:8-9 - The similar size and distance of the sun and moon (one day they will be joined)
In a passage about events on the day of resurrection, the Quran makes an assertion which, critics argue, strongly builds on the implication that the sun and moon are of a similar size and are located a similar distance from Earth. As already noted, the Quran says that the moon "follows" the sun (Quran 91:1-2), and "It is not for the sun to overtake the moon, nor doth the night outstrip the day." (Quran 36:40). Verse Quran 75:8-9 adds that on the last day the sun and moon will be joined together:

And the moon darkens And the sun and the moon are joined,
Quran 75:8-9
The word translated "are joined" is jumi'a, a verb which means to collect together, gather together, bring together.[19] Critics note that this would require the moon to travel 98 million miles away from Earth and into the sun, which is over 400 times wider. To describe them as brought together (jumi'a) in such a scenario would hardly be apt, critics argue, and a very odd apocalyptic event. Rather, the description sits comfortably in the ancient understanding of the cosmos, whereby the sun and moon were assumed to be two roughly equivalent celestial bodies in the sky above the Earth.

It is worth noting that the "darkening" of the moon in verse 8 is an Arabic word which in hadiths refers to a lunar or solar eclipse (in this case lunar). However, for a lunar eclipse to occur (when the earth's shadow is cast upon the moon) the sun and moon are on opposite sides of the earth and thus are not in any sense "joined". Nor does "joined" in verse 9 work as a reference to a solar eclipse (when the sun occasionally casts a shadow of the moon on the earth). The moon is invisible during the portion of a month when it can eclipse the sun since it must be on the daylit side of the earth, and hence the moon does not "darken" or itself become eclipsed (verse 8) as it passes between observers and the sun but rather its silhouette becomes visible.

The sun and its movement is always paired with the moon
The movement of the sun is always mentioned with that of the moon, whether described as running (yajree/tajree) or floating (yasbahoona), or toiling (daibayni). Additionally, in these verses they are nearly always mentioned in the context of night and day (the exception being 13:2), as discussed in an earlier section above.

Here are some of the many verses where the sun and moon are paired (other examples can be found quoted across the article).

A token unto them is night. We strip it of the day, and lo! they are in darkness and the sun runneth on unto a resting-place for him. That is the measuring of the Mighty, the Wise. And for the moon We have appointed mansions till she return like an old shrivelled palm-leaf. It is not for the sun to overtake the moon, nor doth the night outstrip the day. They float each in an orbit.
Quran 36:37-40
And He it is Who created the night and the day, and the sun and the moon. They all float in rounded courses.
Quran 21:33
Do you not see that Allah causes the night to enter the day and causes the day to enter the night and has subjected the sun and the moon, each running [its course] for a specified term, and that Allah, with whatever you do, is Acquainted?
Quran 31:29
He has made subject to you the Night and the Day; the Sun and the moon
Quran 16:12
And He hath made subject to you the Sun and the moon, both diligently pursuing their courses; and the night and the day hath he (also) made subject to you.
Quran 14:33
Among His Signs are the Night and the Day, and the Sun and the Moon. [...]
Quran 41:37
He created the heavens and the earth in true (proportions): He makes the Night overlap the Day, and the Day overlap the Night: He has subjected the sun and the moon (to His law): Each one follows a course for a time appointed. Is not He the Exalted in Power - He Who forgives again and again?
Quran 39:5
Quran 35:11-13 explains that it is not only humans that were created in pairs (male and female), but also the two bodies of flowing waters (one salty and one sweet), the night and the day, and the sun and the moon.

And Allah did create you from dust; then from a sperm-drop; then He made you in pairs. And no female conceives, or lays down (her load), but with His knowledge. Nor is a man long-lived granted length of days, nor is a part cut off from his life, but is in a Decree (ordained). All this is easy to Allah. Nor are the two bodies of flowing water alike,- the one palatable, sweet, and pleasant to drink, and the other, salt and bitter. Yet from each (kind of water) do ye eat flesh fresh and tender, and ye extract ornaments to wear; and thou seest the ships therein that plough the waves, that ye may seek (thus) of the Bounty of Allah that ye may be grateful. He merges Night into Day, and he merges Day into Night, and he has subjected the sun and the moon (to his Law): each one runs its course for a term appointed. Such is Allah your Lord: to Him belongs all Dominion.
Quran 35:11-13
Quran 2:258 - Abraham's challenge: Allah brings the sun from the east, so bring it from the west!
Various verses describe the shape of the sun's course. The general scheme involves Allah bringing the sun from east and the sun traveling high and eventually going back down. Critics and modern Islamic scholars agree, however, that most of these verses are comparable to the kind of convenient colloquialisms we still use today (see Quran 20:059, Quran 20:130, Quran 17:078, Quran 6:77-78, and Quran 18:17). Some of these verses, however, have been the object of considerable debate between the two groups.

Quran 2:258 approvingly quotes a few lines from a debate between Abraham and a disbelieving king, where Abraham replies that Allah brings the sun (yatee biashshamsi يَأْتِى بِٱلشَّمْسِ) from the east. The arabic verb and preposition indicate that the sun is conceived of as physically moving.[20]

Abraham said, ‘Indeed Allah brings the sun from the east; now you bring it from the west.’ So the disbeliever was overwhelmed [by astonishment], and Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people.
Qur'an 2:258
Critics conclude that the Qur'an is clear about the course of the sun: it does not describe a complete orbit, but rather a rounded course, presumably in a hemisphere (falak[1]) that has a beginning, an end, and a highest point.

Quran 18:83-90 - The sun sets in a muddy spring and rises on a people without shelter
Quran 18:83-90 also describes the physical, terrestrial locations where the sun is supposed to rise and set in response to a question about an existing legend. Here, in the Quranic account of life of Dhul Qarnayan or Alexander the Great, the physical setting place of the sun, located in muddy spring, can be seen by human eyes. Indeed, in this account, a human tribe is said to live adjacent to this celestial setting place.

They will ask thee of Dhu'l-Qarneyn. Say: I shall recite unto you a remembrance of him. Lo! We made him strong in the land and gave him unto every thing a road. And he followed a road. Till, when he reached the setting-place of the sun, he found it setting in a muddy spring, and found a people thereabout. We said: O Dhu'l-Qarneyn! Either punish or show them kindness. Then he followed a road. Till, when he reached the rising-place of the sun, he found it rising on a people for whom We had appointed no shelter therefrom.
Quran 18:84-90
There is historical evidence from early Quranic commentaries and other sources, including contemporary Arabic and Syriac poems of the same legend, to the effect that early Muslims took this account literally.

Quran 79:27-29 - The entire heaven has a night and day
The Qur'anic conception of the cosmos accords with its author's visual perception of the sky, even to the extent that in Quran 79:28-29 night and day is mistaken as a feature of the entire heaven. In these verses the night and morning brightness are said to be an attribute of the heaven (l-samāu) which Allah built (banāhā) and raised (rafaʿa) as a ceiling (samkahā) and ordered it (fasawwāhā) when he created the heaven and earth.

Are ye the harder to create, or is the heaven that He built? He raised the height thereof and ordered it; And He made dark the night thereof, and He brought forth the morn thereof. And after that He spread the earth,
Quran 79:27-30
The possessive hā suffix in laylahā (its night) and ḍuḥāhā (its morning light) relates night and day to the heaven in its entirety. In reality, the night and day we experience is a feature of the earth's rotation on its axis. There is no sense in which the earth's night and day (which happen at the same time) apply across the wider cosmos.

In order to confirm the interpretation of these verses it is important to look at how the significant words are used elsewhere in the Quran. "The night" is a very common word in the Quran, and the morning light is used in the same context in Quran 93:1-2-1 and Quran 91:1-1 (see also Quran 79:46).

Indeed, Quran 91:1-6 has many of the same Arabic words as Quran 79:27-30: "its morning light" (this time of the sun), "the night", and "the heaven" (singular) "built" by Allah. Putting the two passages together, it seems that the author of the Quran intuitively believed that the night and the sun's morning light were features pertaining to the entire visible heaven. This does not accord in any way with the modern heliocentric understanding of our local solar system.

Other verses are helpful to confirm what is meant by the heaven (singular) in this context. Quran 2:29 states that Allah turned (is'tawā) to the heaven and fashioned them (fasawwāhunna) seven heavens. These are two forms of the same Arabic verb as is translated "ordered" in Quran 79:28 in the above quote.

He it is Who created for you all that is in the earth. Then turned He to the heaven, and fashioned it as seven heavens. And He is knower of all things.
Quran 2:29
The word "raised" in Quran 79:28 is similarly used for the creation of the heaven (singular) and earth in Quran 88:18 and the heavens (plural) raised without visible pillars in Quran 13:2.

The word "he built it" in v. 27 (banāhā) also occurs in Quran 50:6, which says regarding the heaven (singular) that Allah "built it" and "adorned it" (wazayyannāhā), a word which in other verses refers to the stars or lamps adorning the lowest heaven (Quran 37:6, Quran 41:12 and Quran 67:5).

The regular cycle of the sun
According to several verses in the Qur'an, the sun's cycle is repeated on a regular basis and is comparable in this respect to the orbit of the Moon as well as the cycle of night and day.

[…] He made the Sun and the moon subservient (to you); each one pursues its course to an appointed time; He regulates the affair, making clear the signs
Quran 13:2
Seest thou not that Allah merges night into day and he merges day into night and he has subjected the sun, and the moon each running its course for a term appointed. And Allah is aware of what you do.
Quran 31:29
The Sun and the moon follow courses (exactly) computed
Word by word: Alshamsu (the sun) waalqamaru (and the moon) bihusbanin
Quran 55:5
Husban can mean a number of things: "definite reckoning", "appointed courses", "numbering", "revolving firmament", "running appointed", and "scheduled course". In many English translations the word 'course' or 'celestial sphere' is used. In this verse, the word falak is not used; Quran 55:5 only indicates that the sun and the moon behave in a calculated, scheduled, or otherwise pre-appointed manner. This verse and similar verses are consequently marshalled by critics as further evidence that the Quran espouses a geocentric cosmology, as the sun's daily cycle and the moon's monthly cycle serve ritual timekeeping purposes such as for determining prayer and fasting times in Islam (see next section).

The sun and timekeeping
In Muhammad's lifetime it was common practice to use the sun and moon for timekeeping, which helps explain the emphasis in the Qur'an on the regulated and scheduled nature of the courses of the sun and moon as a sign from Allah and as a divinely sanctioned monthly calendar (see previous section).

He it is that cleaves the day-break (from the dark): He makes the night for rest and tranquility and the sun and moon for the reckoning [of time])
Quran 6:96
Indeed, (the) number (of) the months with Allah (is) twelve months in (the) ordinance (of) Allah (from the) Day He created the heavens and the earth; of them, four (are) sacred. That (is) the religion the upright, so (do) not wrong therein yourselves. And fight the polytheists all together, as they fight you all together. And know that Allah (is) with the righteous.
Quran 9:36
It is He Who made the Sun to be a shining glory and the moon to be a light (of beauty), and measured out stages for her; that ye might know the number of years and the count [of time]. Nowise did Allah create this but in truth and righteousness. (Thus) doth He explain His Signs in detail, for those who have knowledge.
Quran 10:5
And We have made the night and the day two signs, then We have made the sign of the night to pass away and We have made the sign of the day manifest, so that you may seek grace from your Lord, and that you might know the numbering of years and the reckoning; and We have explained everything with distinctness.
Quran 17:12
The moon (the sign, or ayah, of the night) is used to count the years, which comprise the twelve lunar months making up the Islamic year, and the sun is to be used to keep track of time. The only solar movement to be used for timekeeping is the apparent daily course of the sun (from east up and then down to the west). To this day, virtually all mainstream Islamic authorities use the (less precise and regularly unpredictable) lunar calendar to determine the date and the apparent position of the sun from any given location to determine the waqt (prescribed time) of daily salats (prayers). In some cases, as with the Burj Khalifa, which is one of the tallest buildings in the world and which is located in the United Arab Emirates, this means that prayer times differ one the top floor of the building from the prayer times on the bottom floor of the building, as the moment of sunset and sunrise varies as one ascends in elevation.

The sun and the daily prayers
The only examples of the sun being used for timekeeping in the Qur'an employ the sun's apparent daily movement along the sky. Each of the five daily prayers described either directly or indirectly or alluded to in some manner in the Quran. These references all involve mention of the physical, orbital position of the sun. The first prayer, salat al-fajr, takes place right before sun rise and is mentioned in Quran 17:78, Quran 20:130, and Quran 24:58. The second prayer, salat al-zuhr, takes place right after the sun reaches its zenith, but before the shadow of the Sun becomes twice its length from midday. This prayer is possibly mentioned in Quran 17:78 as prayer at the "decline of the sun". The third prayer, salat al-asr, takes place when the sun is between zenith and sunset, when the length of a shadow of a stick is either once or twice its length. This prayer is mentioned in Quran 2:238 as "the middle prayer" and in Quran 20:130 and Quran 50:39 as the "exhalt[ing of Allah] with praise" before the sun's "setting". The fourth prayer, salat al-maghrib, takes place right after sunset. This prayer is not clearly mentioned, but Quran 20:130 and Quran 50:39 mention the "exhalt[ing of Allah] with praise" before rather than after "sunset". The latter verse also mentions "the two ends of the day". The fifth prayer, salat al-isha, takes place at night, between sunset and sunrise. This prayer is mentioned Quran 11:114, Quran 17:79, and Quran 20:130.''

The Qur'an, in various places and contexts, alludes to descriptions of heavenly bodies that seem to suggest a geocentric model of the cosmos. The daily cycle and resting place of the sun, along with the cycles of the sun and moon in relation to night and day, are mentioned in several verses such as Quran 36:37-40. 

One perspective on these verses is that they indicate a geocentric understanding of the universe, as they mention the sun's movement in the context of day and night (Quran 13:2). Critics argue that phrases like "It is not for the sun to overtake the moon" (Quran 36:40) do not comfortably align with a heliocentric perspective, but rather reflect a 7th-century understanding where the sun and moon were believed to orbit the same world.

In Quran 21:33 and 36:40, it is stated that the sun, moon, night, and day all float or swim in an orbit, or falak – a word with various meanings related to the celestial sphere or dome-shaped things. The falak is generally imagined as the place where heavenly bodies revolve, according to classical Arabic lexicons. Some critics argue that the Qur'an's description of the sun and moon's movement supports the idea of geocentrism, as the movement is almost always mentioned in the context of night and day. Another problem with the galactic orbit interpretation, according to critics, is that it is only mentioned in the context of the sun and moon, and not the Earth itself.

Some modern Islamic scholars argue that the sun's movement in the Qur'an refers to its orbit around the Milky Way galaxy rather than a geocentric orbit. However, critics contend that this interpretation is problematic due to the fact that the 225-million-year galactic orbit has no relevance to human time-scales, and that the solar system as a whole revolves around the galaxy, not just the sun.

Additionally, the Qur'an sometimes describes the movement of the sun in a way that its 7th-century listeners were expected to know about, such as in Quran 31:29. Critics point out that this confirms the erroneous 7th-century Arabian knowledge of geocentrism, as it reflects the audience's belief that the sun and moon revolve around the Earth.

In summary, while there are alternative interpretations of the Qur'an's description of the sun, moon, and heavens, critics argue that the most coherent and consistent reading of the text supports a geocentric understanding of the cosmos. The verses discussed above may be seen as providing evidence for this perspective, although different scholars may offer varying interpretations.

The verses 18:86 and 18:90 in Surah al-Kahf of the Qur’an have generated considerable controversy. These verses are part of a larger episode, verses 18:83-101, which narrate the story of Dhu’l Qarnayn, or “Possessor of the two horns”. The passage states that Allah granted Dhu’l Qarnayn power over all things and he used this power to embark on three journeys to strange lands inhabited by different peoples, culminating in a prophecy about the end of times. The controversy surrounding verses 86 and 90 arises from the perception of Muslims that they imply that Allah asserts the sun sets and rises in physical locations and specifically that the sun sets in a muddy spring. While several people have written about these verses, few have addressed the issue in great detail, and therefore, there is a need for more research.

This article aims to present the different interpretations of these verses, along with the evidence supporting them. It also offers new arguments to provide further insight into the matter. The paper will then critically examine each interpretation before reaching its conclusion.

The Surah al-Kahf 83-101 provides a detailed account of Dhu’l Qarnayn’s journey. He was granted power by Allah, who gave him the means to control everything on earth. During his travels, he visited unusual places inhabited by various people. At the end of his journeys, he predicted what would happen in the end-times. Verses 86 and 90 are part of this narration. In verse 86, Dhu’l Qarnayn reaches the place where the sun sets and discovers that it sets in a spring of murky water. In verse 90, he arrives at the place where the sun rises and finds that there is no covering for the people there against the sun. He leaves them as they are, knowing that Allah will take care of them.

This paper will examine each interpretation of verses 86 and 90 and provide arguments in support of each. It will also scrutinize these interpretations critically to arrive at a conclusion.
The Qur’an uses two words to refer to the east and west, al mashriq (east) and al maghrib (west). Al mashriq is derived from the verb ashraqa, which means to rise or shine. It refers to the place or time where the sun rises or shines and is used to mean the east in many verses of the Qur’an. On the other hand, al maghrib means the west or western and is usually translated as such in the Qur’an. Gharb and sharq are adjectival forms of maghrib and mashriq respectively, meaning western or of the west, and eastern or of the east respectively.

In verse 18:86, alshshamsi (of the sun) is added to maghriba to mean the place of sunset. Lane's Lexicon of classical Arabic, an authoritative source, states that maghrib originally signified the place or point of sunset, which is the meaning when alshshamsi is added. However, this is not used in other instances of maghrib in the Qur'an, and alshshams is not even used with maghrib when it means the west anywhere in the hadith. Similarly, in verse 18:90, matliAAa alshshamsi means the place of the sunrise. However, matliAA, with or without alshshams, is not used to mean east anywhere else in the Qur’an nor in the hadith.

If verse 18:90 was about the east, then al mashriq or al sharq would likely have been used instead of matliAAa alshshamsi. Every verse in the Qur’an that uses maghrib to mean west also uses mashriq to mean east. The verse would probably also replace tatluAAu with tashruqu for aesthetic reasons if it were about the east. The Lexicon gives no indication that matliAA, with or without alshshamsi, or related words like talaAAa, can be used in an idiom meaning the east.

The phrase matliAAi alshshamsi is used in Sahih Muslim to mean “of sunrise,” literally meaning the direction of the rising-place of the sun. In the very next hadith, the phrase is translated as qibala almashriqi, meaning the direction of the east. 

Commentators of the Quran have used knowledge that was not known during the 7th century Arab era. Although there were classical commentators who believed that Dhu'l Qarnayn reached the east and west, there were commentators such as al-Qurtubi and al-Razi who denied this interpretation, based on their knowledge of the world. Their reasoning was not based on linguistic or contextual analysis, but rather on their understanding that the interpretation was impossible. For example, they claimed that the sun was too large to touch or that the concept of the sun setting on people was not realistic. These commentators, however, were not likely to have been known to Muhammad and the earliest Muslim community. This knowledge came to the Arabs after the translation of Ptolemy's Almagest into Arabic in the 8th century CE.

As the worldview of educated Muslims incorporated principles of astrology, including the geocentric, spherical, Aristotelian-Ptolemaic world picture, the meaning of the Quran's tales came to be interpreted in later Islamic tradition not according to the biblical-quranic cosmology, which became obsolete, but according to the Ptolemaic model. This is the interpretation that the Quran is understood to follow today.

Before Islam, the Arabs had a simple yet developed astronomical folklore of a practical nature. They had knowledge of the risings and settings of stars, associated with the cosmical setting of groups of stars and simultaneous heliacal risings of others, which marked the beginning of periods called naw’. Ptolemy's Almagest was translated at least five times in the late eighth and ninth centuries, which introduced Greek planetary models, uranometry, and mathematical methods to the Muslims.

Hijab cites Quranic verse Surah Ya-Sin, 36:38 in support of his argument, which describes the sun moving on a fixed course, similar to the heliocentric model of the universe. However, this verse does not explicitly endorse his interpretation that the sun prostrates beneath Allah's throne.

Furthermore, Hijab contends that the Hadith may relate to a specific time-bound destination, such as the Day of Judgment. This claim faces challenges, as the Hadith explicitly states that the sun prostrates beneath Allah's throne and seeks permission to rise again, implying a daily cycle of ascension and descent, rather than a unique event associated only with the Day of Judgment.

Additionally, an account in which Prophet Muhammad inquires about the sun's position at sunset contradicts the idea that the seven heavens lie beneath Allah's throne. In this account, the companion replies that the sun goes beneath Allah's throne and seeks permission to rise again, suggesting that the Prophet was unaware of the Earth's spherical shape and the heliocentric model.

Hijab seems to have sidestepped critical questions related to the Hadith, such as the sun’s capacity to communicate with God, the absence of references to Judgment Day in the Hadith, and the necessity for Allah to clarify the sun's movement through space with regards to Judgment Day. Additionally, why would the Prophet mention the sun prostrating under the throne in the Hadith if the sun is always beneath Allah's throne?

The presence of metaphors, anthropomorphism, and eschatology in the Quran raises doubts about why Allah did not provide clearer explanations of celestial objects and natural phenomena, opting instead for ambiguous and outdated descriptions.

His reasoning relies on linguistic acrobatics to disregard obvious contradictions, rather than presenting a coherent, scientifically-compatible interpretation.

In Quran 55:17, Allah refers to Himself as “the Lord of the two Easts and the Lord of the two Wests.” This verse implies that a location considered as “west” for one person may be “east” for another person viewing from a different perspective; when someone witnesses a sunset, someone else will simultaneously observe a sunrise at the same location. Consequently, there are two Easts and two Wests relative to the perspectives of two distant observers. This concept indicates that the sun is perpetually setting and rising concerning each observer’s location, which is consistent with the Theory of Relativity.

The Quran alludes to descriptions of celestial bodies in various contexts that seem to suggest a geocentric model of the cosmos. It mentions the daily cycle and resting place of the sun, as well as the cycles of the sun and moon in relation to night and day, in several verses such as Quran 36:37-40.

Critics argue that these verses indicate a geocentric understanding of the universe, as they mention the sun's movement in the context of day and night (Quran 13:2), and that phrases like “It is not for the sun to overtake the moon” (Quran 36:40) do not comfortably align with a heliocentric perspective, but instead reflect a 7th-century understanding of the cosmos, where the sun and moon were believed to orbit Earth.

Furthermore, in Quran 21:33 and 36:40, it states that the sun, moon, night, and day all float or swim in an orbit or falak, a word with various meanings related to celestial spheres or domed objects. Critics contend that the Quran's description of the sun and moon's movement supports the idea of geocentrism since their movement is frequently mentioned in the context of night and day.

Lastly, some critics argue that the modern interpretation of the sun's movement in the Quran as an orbit around the Milky Way galaxy is problematic, as the 225-million-year galactic orbit is not relevant to human time-scales, and the solar system as a whole revolves around the galaxy, not just the sun.

''Earth created before stars
The elements in the Earth's crust and core were first formed in stars by nucleosynthesis. When those stars exploded as supernovas, they expelled the elements that were used in future solar systems such as Earth's own. Modern radiometric dating of meteorites and rocks from the Earth and Moon show that these bodies were formed at the same time as the sun and its other planets, 4.5 billion years ago. The Qur'an, on the other hand, describes the Earth as being fully formed before the stars.

Quran 41:12 states that lamps (or more specifically, stars in the similar verse Quran 37:6) were placed in the nearest of the seven heavens. But before there were seven heavens and while heaven was just smoke, the Earth already existed according to the previous verse, Quran 41:11, and the Earth's creation and completion in the preceding days is described in the verses immediately preceeding that one Quran 41:9-10, discussed in the previous section above. The creation sequence is thus as follows:

Heaven and completed Earth;
Seven heavens and each given its mandate;
The nearest heaven adorned with stars and guarded.
Then turned He to the heaven when it was smoke, and said unto it and unto the earth: Come both of you, willingly or loth. They said: We come, obedient. Then He ordained them seven heavens in two Days and inspired in each heaven its mandate; and We decked the nether heaven with lamps, and rendered it inviolable. That is the measuring of the Mighty, the Knower.
Quran 41:11-12
Quran 2:29 further confirms that heaven was only fashioned seven heavens when, according to the Quran, everything on Earth had been created.

He it is Who created for you all that is in the earth. Then turned He to the heaven, and fashioned it as seven heavens. And He is knower of all things.
Quran 2:29
The word lamps (masabeeha مَصَٰبِيحَ) in Quran 41:12 and Quran 67:5 with which Allah adorns (zayyanna زَيَّنَّا) the lowest heaven would need, of course, to include any luminous bodies such as the stars. Aquí se está hablando de las perfecciones, Aquino aquí hace la distinción entre perfecciones puras y mixtas.
Mixtas son aquellas que incluyen algún tipo de limitación o imperfección, como por ejemplo, que algo sea color rojo, esto significa que es extenso, por lo cual es divisible y si es divisible es corruptible, y esta es una perfección. Los trascendentales se dan en absolutamente todos los entes sin excepción, por el simple hecho de existir.
Con esto el argumento halla su razón de ser en que la existencia de estos grados de perfección trascendentales, debe ser explicada por la existencia de un ser que las posea todas en modo máximo y por esencia.
Así pues, el argumento se basa en estos grados de perfección trascendentales, no en cualquier grado de cualquier cosa que se te ocurre como Dawkins pone el ejemplo de hediondez o en un ejemplo de la enfermedad o peste, por eso es un hombre de paja.

Aunque es cierto que Aquino se enfoca en las perfecciones trascendentales y puras en su cuarta vía, hay quienes argumentan que este enfoque está limitado y no es suficientemente sólido como para demostrar la existencia de un ser supremo.

En primer lugar, cabe preguntarse si las perfecciones trascendentales son verdaderamente objetivas y universales, o más bien producto de nuestra percepción y entendimiento. Podría ser que, como seres humanos, atribuimos valor a ciertas cualidades como la belleza, la bondad y la verdad debido a nuestra educación, cultura y experiencias personales. Si este fuera el caso, entonces las perfecciones trascendentales que Aquino considera tan importantes serían simplemente constructos subjetivos y no verdades fundamentales del universo.

Además, aunque aceptáramos la existencia de perfecciones trascendentales objetivas, aún podríamos cuestionar el supuesto de que necesariamente implique la existencia de un ser supremo que las posea en modo máximo y por esencia. Es posible que estos atributos existan simplemente como parte de la diversidad inherente del universo y no se deriven de una entidad omnipotente y omnisciente. De esta manera, los distintos grados de perfección en los entes no indicarían la presencia de un ser supremo sino simplemente la manifestación de la variedad y complejidad del mundo.

Además, si bien Dawkins recurre a ejemplos como la hediondez o la enfermedad para ilustrar su crítica a la cuarta vía, este tipo de contraejemplos ponen en evidencia uno de los principales problemas del argumento de Aquino: es altamente selectivo en cuanto a qué propiedades considera "perfecciones" y cuáles no. Si la cuarta vía se basa en la existencia de grados de perfección trascendentales, entonces podría argumentarse que es igualmente válido basar la existencia de Dios en grados de imperfectos o indeseables.

En última instancia, aunque la cuarta vía de Aquino presenta ideas interesantes sobre las perfecciones trascendentales y su relación con el ente supremo, estos argumentos no son concluyentes ni suficientes para establecer sólidamente la existencia de un ser supremo. Hay muchas objeciones y debilidades en este argumento, lo que deja abierto el debate y la discusión sobre este tema.
sE podria decir que es caer en Antropomorfismo?

Sí, podría argumentarse que la cuarta vía de Aquino cae en cierto grado de antropomorfismo. El antropomorfismo es la tendencia a atribuir características o propiedades humanas a seres no humanos o a conceptos abstractos. En el caso de la cuarta vía, Aquino atribuye perfecciones trascendentales, como la bondad, la unidad, la verdad, y la belleza, a la idea de un ser supremo. Estas propiedades, aunque consideradas universales por Aquino, podrían entenderse como características humanas o productos de nuestra percepción y experiencias como seres humanos.

Si consideramos que las perfecciones trascendentales son en realidad constructos humanos, el supuesto de un ser supremo que las posee en su grado máximo sería también una creación de nuestra mente. En este sentido, la cuarta vía estaría antropomorfizando la idea de un ser supremo, al atribuirle cualidades que son producto de nuestra propia comprensión y apreciación del mundo.

No obstante, es importante mencionar que Aquino no atribuye todas las características humanas a un ser supremo, es decir, no está describiendo a Dios como un ser humano en sentido estricto. Sin embargo, el enfoque en las perfecciones trascendentales podría entenderse como una forma de antropomorfismo conceptual.
Qué responde dawkins a las críticas de que no presentó la vía correctamente?

El argumento principal de Richard Dawkins en su libro "El Espectáculo de La Ilusión (The God Delusion)" es que la existencia de Dios es una hipótesis altamente improbable. Dawkins critica las diversas pruebas de la existencia de un ser supremo, incluida la cuarta vía de Tomás de Aquino. No obstante, sus críticas al enfoque de Aquino se han encontrado con la objeción de que no presenta correctamente este argumento.

Dawkins sostiene que los grados de perfección o de cualquier otra propiedad no pueden utilizarse para probar la existencia de un ser supremo, ofreciendo ejemplos como enfermedades o hediondez. Estas críticas se han considerado como una representación errónea o simplista de la cuarta vía, considerando que Aquino se basa principalmente en perfecciones trascendentales. 

En respuesta a tales críticas, Dawkins ha mantenido su posición escéptica respecto a las pruebas teológicas sobre la existencia de Dios. Dawkins argumenta que las explicaciones basadas en un ser supremo son más complicadas e improbables que las explicaciones naturalistas que no requieren la intervención de una entidad divina. Además, ha señalado las inconsistencias y contradicciones en los argumentos religiosos y ha criticado la falta de evidencia científica directa para apoyar la existencia de Dios.

Dawkins podría responder a las críticas sobre sus interpretaciones de las vías de Aquino destacando que, incluso si se presentan correctamente, estos argumentos no son suficientemente sólidos ni proporcionan una prueba concluyente de la existencia de Dios. En última instancia, Dawkins se basa en la aplicación del pensamiento crítico y de la ciencia para evaluar y refutar las afirmaciones religiosas, incluidas las de Tomás de Aquino.

1. La existencia de una realidad objetiva: La ciencia asume que hay un mundo real e independiente de nuestras percepciones que puede ser estudiado y conocido. Este supuesto se basa en el realismo ontológico, la creencia de que el mundo existe independientemente de nuestra conciencia y experiencia de él.

2. La inteligibilidad del mundo natural: La ciencia supone que el mundo natural se puede entender y describir a través de leyes y principios. Esta idea se basa en el supuesto filosófico de que el mundo es ordenado y coherentemente estructurado.

3. La importancia de la observación y la experiencia empírica: La ciencia se basa en el empirismo, la creencia filosófica de que el conocimiento se adquiere principalmente a través de la experiencia sensorial. La ciencia valora la observación y la experimentación como medios fundamentales para adquirir información confiable sobre el mundo natural.

4. El valor de la racionalidad y el pensamiento lógico: La ciencia depende del razonamiento lógico y análisis, que son aspectos clave de la filosofía. La ciencia se basa en deducciones e inferencias lógicas a partir de datos observados y en la evaluación crítica de las teorías y explicaciones propuestas.

5. La falibilidad y provisionalidad del conocimiento científico: La ciencia reconoce que su conocimiento es falible y siempre está sujeto a revisión a medida que se obtienen nuevos datos y se formulan nuevas teorías. Este enfoque se basa en la idea filosófica de que el conocimiento es provisional y siempre sujeto a ajustes a medida que avanza nuestra comprensión del mundo.

En resumen, aunque la ciencia ha desarrollado sus propias metodologías y herramientas específicas, sus fundamentos y supuestos están enraizados en la filosofía. Ambas disciplinas contribuyen de manera esencial a nuestra comprensión del mundo y nuestra búsqueda de la verdad.
Qué valor tienen las ideas trascendentales?

Algunas de estas propiedades trascendentales incluyen la unidad, la verdad, la bondad y la belleza.

En el contexto filosófico, las ideas trascendentales tienen valor en varios aspectos:

2. Facilitan la comunicación y el debate intelectual: Dado que las propiedades trascendentales se consideran universales, proporcionan un marco común y compartido en discusiones filosóficas y metafísicas. 3. Conexión con nuestra experiencia y percepción del mundo: Las ideas trascendentales también nos permiten reflexionar sobre cómo experimentamos el mundo y cómo nuestro pensamiento y lenguaje se relacionan con la realidad. Por ejemplo, las propiedades trascendentales como la unidad y la verdad pueden ayudarnos a explorar cómo nuestra mente organiza y comprende la información que obtenemos de nuestra experiencia.

Contribución en la ética y la estética: Las ideas trascendentales como la bondad y la belleza también tienen implicaciones para la ética y la estética, ya que pueden ser fundamentales en nuestra evaluación y apreciación de acciones, comportamientos y objetos. Estas propiedades nos permiten reflexionar sobre valores morales y estéticos en un contexto más amplio y trascendental.

En resumen, las ideas trascendentales tienen un valor importante en la filosofía, ya que nos permiten abordar y analizar los conceptos fundamentales y universales relacionados con la realidad, el conocimiento y la experiencia humana. Sirven como una base común para la comunicación y el debate intelectual y tienen implicaciones significativas en áreas como la ética, la estética y la metafísica.
La metafísica genera conocimiento?

Aunque no genera conocimiento en el mismo sentido que la ciencia, cuyo enfoque es empírico y experimental, la metafísica sí contribuye al conocimiento de manera conceptual y abstracta. Explora aspectos del mundo y del ser que son difíciles o incluso imposibles de investigar utilizando únicamente métodos científicos.

Entre las contribuciones de la metafísica al conocimiento, podemos considerar lo siguiente:

1. Clarificación de conceptos fundamentales: La metafísica nos ayuda a reflexionar y analizar conceptos básicos como la existencia, la identidad, el tiempo y el espacio. Esto puede ayudarnos a examinar nuestras presuposiciones y a esclarecer nuestras ideas sobre la realidad en general.

3. Estimulación de la reflexión crítica: La metafísica nos anima a cuestionar suposiciones y creencias, lo que puede impulsar nuevos descubrimientos y avances en otras áreas del conocimiento. Al desafiar nuestras perspectivas, la metafísica puede abrir nuevas vías de investigación y fomentar la innovación.

4. Examinar las implicaciones de la ciencia: La metafísica también tiene un papel en la ciencia, en la medida en que ayuda a analizar e interpretar los datos y descubrimientos científicos. La metafísica puede informarnos sobre las implicaciones ontológicas o epistemológicas de ciertas teorías científicas y ayudarnos a entender cómo se relacionan con nuestro conocimiento general del mundo.

Aunque la metafísica no genera conocimiento en el sentido más directo y concreto que la ciencia, sigue siendo una herramienta valiosa y fundamental en nuestra búsqueda de comprensión y conocimiento. La metafísica trabaja en coordinación con otras áreas de la filosofía y disciplinas académicas para desarrollar una imagen más completa de la realidad y la existencia.

conversation.content: What was the French Directory and how did it operate?

The French Directory was a five-member executive body that governed France from 1795 to 1799 during the latter stages of the French Revolution. It was established by the Constitution of the Year III, a new constitution which sought to provide a more moderate and stable government after the radical and unstable period of the Jacobin Reign of Terror. The French Directory operated as a collective executive, with the five members sharing power and supposedly serving as a system of checks and balances against any one individual gaining too much power.

The members of the Directory, known as Directors, were elected by the French legislative branch. The election process involved two houses: the Council of Five Hundred, which proposed candidates, and the Council of Ancients, which elected Directors from the nominees. Each of the five members served a term of five years, with one Director being replaced every year to ensure continuity in governance.

The French Directory had several responsibilities, including managing foreign relations, war efforts, public finances, and internal administration. The Directors acted together in their decision-making, and a majority was needed for any action to be taken.

Despite being designed as a more stable and moderate government, the French Directory faced many challenges during its existence. It struggled with economic difficulties, significant internal divisions, and external threats from foreign enemies. The Directory's downfall ultimately came as a result of a coup led by Napoleon Bonaparte in 1799. After the coup, the French government was restructured again, leading to the Consulate era, with Napoleon as its first consul, further consolidating his power and eventually becoming Emperor of the French in 1804.

conversation.content: 唯心主义认识的缺陷

唯心主义是一种关于世界和自然的哲学观点，它认为世界是由精神、意识、意念等抽象的精神因素构成的。唯心主义在认识论上有很多缺陷，主要体现在以下几个方面：

1. 忽视现实客观存在：唯心主义认为现实是由人们心灵和意识创造出来的，否认物质世界在心灵之外的客观存在。这种观点不符合科学原则，不利于对现实世界的深刻认识。

2. 排斥实证观察和实验方法：唯心主义依赖对抽象概念的思考和内省，往往对直接观察和实际实验的重要性不够认同。许多唯心主义哲学家会将自己的观念奉为绝对真理，从而导致他们无法理性地接受科学实验证据。

3. 对科学发展的制约：唯心主义倾向于将各种现象归因于抽象的思想因素，如上帝、天命等，这种观点不利于科学知识的积累和传播，曾经给科学知识的发展带来很大的阻碍。

4. 学术独裁和保守主义：很多唯心主义者将自己的观念和信仰奉为绝对真理，对其他观点和不符合他们信仰的事物充满偏见和排斥。这种僵化的思维方式不利于知识的创新和学术界的交流。

5. 唯心主义很容易滋生教条主义、决定论、怀疑论等负面哲学思潮，这些思潮往往将哲学推到极端，导致对现实问题的解决变得更加困难。

总之，唯心主义认识的缺陷主要表现为过分强调精神因素、忽视现实、排斥实验证据、限制科学发展等方面。但是，我们也不能完全否定唯心主义的贡献，在很多方面，唯心主义可以起到补充和完善唯物主义的作用。我们应该以科学的态度客观地对待唯心主义，取其精华，弃其糟粕。
