An ancient power long dormant within Iolana, waiting for the right moment to once again awake, even as the unsuspecting girl lay dreaming of her future.

The next day marked the beginning of Iolana’s greatest adventure, one filled with friendship, trials, and self-discovery. But it would also be an adventure that would lead her into a dangerous world of secrets and lies, where the power of an ancient Pokémon would threaten to change everything she thought she knew about herself and the world around her.


Chapter 2: A New Companion

The morning sun shone brightly over Alola as Iolana set out on her new adventure. Excited to meet her first partner Pokémon, she hurried to the laboratory of the local Pokémon Professor.

As Iolana arrived at the lab, she found her best friend, Kai, already waiting there for her, his face beaming with enthusiasm. They had grown up together, and despite Kai’s troubled past, he had remained a cheerful, upbeat boy with an unwavering love for Pokémon.

“Hey, Iolana!” Kai called, waving energetically. “I got here early so we could choose our starter Pokémon together! I’ve been dreaming about this moment for as long as I can remember.”

Smiling, Iolana replied, “Me too, Kai! Let’s go meet our new partners!”

The two friends entered the laboratory, eager to begin their adventure together. Inside, they were greeted by the Pokémon Professor. “Ah, you must be Iolana and Kai!” the Professor said warmly. “I’m Professor Koa, and I’ve been studying Pokémon here in Alola for many years. You must be excited to begin your journey. Now, let’s see which Pokémon you’ll be starting with.”

As Iolana and Kai examined the available Pokémon, they were instantly drawn to two very different creatures: Cyndaquil, a small fire-type Pokémon, and Oshawott, an adorable water-type. They knew they had made their choices as soon as their eyes met their future partners.

Excitedly, they accepted their new Pokémon partners from Professor Koa, who then handed them each a Pokédex. “This will help you keep track of the Pokémon you encounter and learn important information about them. Good luck on your journey, and remember to always treat your Pokémon with love and respect.”

With their new partners – Oshawott for Kai, and Cyndaquil for Iolana – and their trusty Pokédexes in hand, the two friends began their journey together in high spirits.

Despite the challenges brought on by Kai’s family situation, he had held onto his boundless enthusiasm and passion for Pokémon. As Iolana and Kai embarked on their adventure, they knew they could count on each other to make this a journey they would never forget.

However, as the two trainers set out to explore the world and grow stronger with their Pokémon, the shadows of Iolana’s past and Kai’s difficult family life continued to loom over their friendship. The trials that awaited them would challenge their bond and force them to confront the dark secrets buried deep within their own lives.

But for now, Iolana and Kai had each other, and their loyal Pokémon companions would accompany them every step of the way. Together, they would face whatever challenges awaited them with courage and an unbreakable bond of friendship.


Chapter 3: The First Battle

The sun blazed over the beautiful island of Alola as Iolana and Kai began their journey as Pokémon trainers. With their new partners by their side, they agreed that the best way to start their adventure was to test themselves in a friendly Pokémon battle. The excitement in the air was palpable as they found a suitable spot on the soft sands of a nearby beach.

“Alright, Iolana,” said Kai, his eyes filled with determination as he looked at his best friend. “Let’s promise that no matter what happens, we’ll help each other to grow stronger and become great Pokémon trainers.”

Iolana smiled, her eyes shimmering with confidence. “Absolutely, Kai! Let’s do this!”

With a nod of agreement, they took their positions on the sandy battleground. “Go, Cyndaquil!” Iolana shouted, releasing her new partner Pokémon from its Pokéball.

In response, Kai threw his Pokéball into the air, calling out his beloved Oshawott. “Alright, Oshawott, it’s showtime!”

As their Pokémon faced each other, Iolana and Kai couldn’t help but feel a sense of pride in their new partnership. “Cyndaquil, use Tackle!” Iolana commanded, watching as her Pokémon charged toward its opponent.

Kai quickly countered, “Oshawott, dodge and use Water Gun!” Oshawott swiftly sidestepped Cyndaquil’s attack and unleashed a powerful stream of water from its mouth, hitting the fire-type Pokémon with surprising accuracy.

The battle continued, with both trainers giving their all as they directed their Pokémon’s movements. With each attack, dodge, and block, Iolana and Kai learned more about their partners’ strengths, weaknesses, and potential.

After a heated exchange of moves, the young trainers eventually called a truce, realizing that their Pokémon were exhausted from their first battle. However, both Iolana and Kai had grown stronger through the experience, and they were more determined than ever to help each other grow.

As they tended to their weary Pokémon, Iolana looked at Kai and said, “We promised that we’d help each other become great trainers, and I know we’ll keep that promise. I’m so glad I have you beside me on this journey.”

Kai smiled back at her. “I feel the same way, Iolana. With you and our Pokémon, I know we’ll face any challenge that comes our way.”

As the friends continued their adventure, they were reminded of their unwavering commitment to each other and their Pokémon. Together, they would face countless battles, difficult trials, and the shadows of their own pasts.

But through it all, Iolana and Kai knew that no matter what obstacles they encountered, they could count on their friendship, and the love and support of their Pokémon, to see them through.


Chapter 4: A Bittersweet Moment

As Iolana and Kai ventured deeper into the Alolan landscape, they found themselves wandering through lush forests and exploring winding trails, all while strengthening their bond with each other and their Pokémon.

During a break in their journey, the two friends found themselves sitting down below the shade of a tall, leafy tree. They began a heartfelt conversation about their dreams, their pasts, and how much their friendship meant to each of them.

“I can’t imagine doing this without you, Iolana,” Kai confessed as they watched their Pokémon play nearby. “There have been so many times in my life where I felt completely alone, but having you by my side has made all the difference.”

Iolana’s heart ached for her friend, knowing all too well the pain of losing loved ones and the turmoil it had caused in his life. “We’ve always been there for each other, Kai. You’re like family to me, and I know that we can face anything together.”

The friends shared a quiet, comforting moment as they basked in the warmth of their bond. However, their peace was suddenly interrupted by the sound of Kai’s PokéGear ringing. He glanced at the screen and hesitated before answering the call.

“Hey, Dad,” Kai greeted tentatively, trying his best to sound cheerful. He listened intently for a moment before his face fell, disappointment creeping into his voice. “Oh, you can’t come home today? I understand… No, it’s alright. Don’t worry about me. I’ll see you soon.”

As he hung up the call, Kai bit his lip, struggling to contain his disappointment. He had been looking forward to showing his father his new partner, Oshawott, and sharing his excitement about his new journey as a Pokémon trainer.

Iolana looked at Kai with concern, sensing that their conversation had not gone well. “Is everything okay, Kai?” she asked gently.

With a shaky breath, Kai forced a smile onto his face, trying to mask his hurt. “Yeah, it’s fine. I was just hoping that my dad could see Oshawott, but he’s really busy with work at the Aether Foundation. It’s not a big deal.”

Iolana squeezed her friend’s hand reassuringly. “I’m sure your dad is proud of you, Kai. He just has a lot on his plate right now. And don’t forget, you’ve got me right here to share all of your journey’s best moments with.”

Kai’s eyes shimmered with gratitude as he genuinely smiled back at Iolana. “You’re right, Iolana. Thanks for always being there for me.”

As their journey continued, Iolana and Kai would find that their greatest strength lay not only in their Pokémon partners but also in the depth of their friendship and their unwavering support for one another. Amid the challenges of battles, the shadows of their pasts, and the unexpected trials that awaited them, they knew they could face anything, as long as they did it together.


Chapter 5: A Hidden Connection

Meanwhile, in the bustling city of Castelia, in the Unova region, a talented young journalist named Aelfrun fought to make a name for herself among the competitive throngs of the metropolis. With her keen intuition and ambition, Aelfrun had managed to carve out a fulfilling life for herself, albeit one weighed down by tragic memories and a haunting past.

Aelfrun’s parents had been brilliant scientists, working on something they referred to as “Project Infinity.” But beneath the mysterious name, they had never revealed the true nature of their work to their young daughter. When she was a baby, Aelfrun had suffered from a life-threatening heart condition, Tetralogy of Fallot. Desperate to save their daughter’s life, her parents had infused her with the very same experimental serum they had been studying—cells from the legendary Pokémon, Xerneas.

This dangerous procedure had left Aelfrun with not only a healthy heart but also the latent power of the Mythical Pokémon. What her parents never expected, however, was the unanticipated consequences of their experiment: Project Infinity had sown seeds of great tragedy in the lives of everyone it touched.

As a child, Aelfrun had dreamed of becoming a Pokémon Master. At the age of twelve, she had even managed to collect all of the elusive badges from Pokémon gyms throughout the Unova region. But when Aelfrun returned home from her journey, she was greeted with heartbreak. Her parents had perished in a devastating accident at the Research and Incubation Facility 06—the very same incident that had brought chaos to Iolana’s life.

The loss of her parents shattered Aelfrun’s dreams of becoming a Pokémon Master, and she had eventually turned her focus to journalism in an attempt to heal her grief-stricken heart. Yet, unknowingly, her life remained entangled with the remnants of Project Infinity and the fate of Iolana.

As Aelfrun continued her work, she began to uncover hints of secrets hidden within the Unovan government. Something drew her to investigate the matter further, a deep-rooted intuition that these secrets would lead her to the truth about the tragic fate of her parents and herself. Little did Aelfrun know that her investigation would connect her to Iolana’s past and uncover the buried connection between them—their shared legacy as the unwitting children of Project Infinity.

Through their shared journey towards self-discovery, Iolana, Kai, and Aelfrun would soon find themselves entwined in a powerful tale of destiny, friendship, and the ultimate courage required to embrace their true potential.

As they delved deeper into the mysteries of life, choices would have to be made, sacrifices faced, and only the most indomitable bond of friendship would see them through the challenges that lay ahead.


Chapter 6: Encountering the Unknown

The hustle and bustle of Castelia city never seemed to slow down, even as the evening sun dipped below the towering skyscrapers. Aelfrun’s life as a newspaper reporter in Unova’s largest metropolis left her little time to ponder the mysteries of her past or the suspicions lingering in her mind about Project Infinity.

One autumn evening, Aelfrun found herself sitting at her desk in the cramped office she shared with other ambitious reporters, sifting through a stack of stories and leads in search of something compelling to investigate. As she combed through the articles, one particular headline caught her eye: “UFO Sighting Reported in District 54—A Mysterious Connection?”

Intrigued, Aelfrun began to read the eyewitness accounts of strange lights seen streaking across the sky in the remote outskirts of Castelia. Those who had witnessed the phenomenon whispered rumors of government cover-ups, secret experiments, and “visitors” from other worlds. This was a far cry from Aelfrun’s usual investigative subjects, but something about the story spoke to her, resonating with a buried instinct she couldn’t quite grasp.

Following her intuition, she decided to investigate the UFO sightings and the urban legend surrounding District 54. Perhaps it would lead her to some answers about the elusive Project Infinity and the mysterious events that had upturned so many lives.

Over the following weeks, Aelfrun delved deeper into the tale of District 54, tirelessly scanning old newspapers, scouring local archives, and conducting interviews with those who claimed to have seen the mysterious lights. Slowly, she began to piece together a fragmented puzzle that hinted at hidden truths and long-forgotten connections.

As she delved further, she discovered that District 54 had once been home to a government research facility, which had been destroyed in a catastrophe—an event that had marked the end of Project Infinity. Aelfrun couldn’t help but feel a prickle run down her spine at the realization that this shared past with Iolana was no coincidence, and that their fates were somehow inextricably linked.

Unbeknownst to her, the threads of Aelfrun’s investigation were reaching across the seas to the Alolan region, weaving an intricate web that would soon entangle the lives of Iolana, Kai, and herself in a tumultuous tapestry of secrets, friendship, and an epic exploration of life’s true essence.

As Aelfrun continued to unravel the mysteries of District 54, she found herself drawn closer and closer to the truth about her own origins, the powerful bond that connected her with Iolana, and the destiny that awaited them both. Yet, as Aelfrun would soon learn, the path to clarity is seldom a straight one, and only the most steadfast hearts can navigate the treacherous turns that lay ahead.


Chapter 7: The Heart of Darkness

Aelfrun’s search for the hidden truths of District 54 brought her to the remains of Research and Incubation Facility 06. The abandoned structure loomed ominously, a haunting reminder of the tragedy and devastation that had occurred within its walls. Undeterred, Aelfrun ventured through the crumbling corridors, her heart pounding with each step further into the darkness.

The air was thick with an eerie silence, pierced only by Aelfrun’s ragged breath and anxious footfalls. As she delved deeper into the heart of the facility, Aelfrun stumbled upon a hidden chamber, its entrance concealed by the ruins and debris. Overcoming her overwhelming anxiety, Aelfrun approached the chamber cautiously.

Inside, she found it—the blood-red glowing feather, a symbol of power, despair, and a long-buried secret. As she reached out to touch it, an immense energy surged into her being, consuming her vision with searing images of the tragic day when both Project Infinity and her parents had met their tragic end.

In that moment of chaos and pain, Aelfrun’s connection to Iolana and the experiment that had bound them since childhood grew ever stronger. The intensity of the energy seared her skin, and she instinctively dropped the feather, gasping for breath amid the swirling shadows of her memories. Every fiber of her being ached to take the feather from this forsaken place and bring it to Iolana, but fate had other plans.

As Aelfrun turned her back on the dark chamber and the secrets that still lingered within, she was met with a sudden and violent force. The shock of the taser stunned her, and she crumpled to the ground, the pain washing over her like a crashing wave.

As the agents of the Ministry of Defence descended upon her, Aelfrun’s heart raced—filled with dread and determination. Her mind swam with questions and the enormity of what she had just discovered, but one thing was clear: she would not allow the feather or the secrets hidden within District 54 to remain hidden.

As the black hood descended over Aelfrun’s face, her fate intertwined ever more closely with that of Iolana and Kai. The trials to come would test their strength, courage, and their unshakeable bond, but together they would uncover the ultimate truth behind the mysteries that had shaped their lives—and perhaps, through their shared destiny, break the curse that had haunted them since the day their hearts had first begun to beat.


Chapter 8: Interrogation and Revelation

Aelfrun’s body ached with the intensity of the shock as she was hauled to her feet by her captors. She could feel the beads of sweat forming on her brow, her breathing shallow and labored under the black hood covering her face. Her mind raced with questions and fear but, beneath it all, a spark of indignant anger stoked a fire within her heart.

The agents of the Ministry of Defence guided Aelfrun through the winding facility, dragging her into a sterile, windowless room. As they forcibly seated her in a cold metal chair, the cacophony of their footsteps reverberated on the solid concrete floor. The slap of a floodlight snapping on pierced the darkness, even as her eyes remained shrouded under the hood.

A booming voice echoed throughout the room, “Miss Aelfrun Wyndsor, do you know where you are?” The smooth, abrasive tone put her on edge instantly.

For a brief moment, Aelfrun hesitated and considered remaining silent. But ultimately, she knew that to understand the depths of the mysteries that had plagued her entire life, she needed to respond. Her voice, defiant but trembling ever so slightly, responded, “Yes.”

A cruel laugh reverberated throughout the room. “You’ve come a long way in search of secrets, Miss Wyndsor,” the voice taunted. “But you’ve ventured too far and now find yourself imprisoned by those you sought to expose.”

The agents roughly lifted the hood from Aelfrun’s face. As her eyes struggled to adjust to the sudden influx of light, she squinted at the man before her—a tall man with balding gray hair, wearing a crisp military uniform. His eyes held an unsettling mixture of amusement and malice.

“You must know that digging into the Ministry’s buried secrets will only lead to pain and suffering,” he continued calmly. “So, tell me, Miss Wyndsor, what would you hope to gain by delving into the past?”

Aelfrun’s eyes flashed with determination, her voice unwavering as she responded, “Answers. I deserve to know the truth about Project Infinity, the research my parents were involved in, and how it has shaped my own existence. This tragedy has haunted me for years, and I am tired of living in the shadow of unanswered questions.”

The man smiled menacingly, leaning in closer to Aelfrun’s face. “Perhaps,” he said, his voice dripping with malice, “your questions are better left unanswered, Miss Wyndsor. The truth can sometimes be more devastating than the lies we cling to.”

For a moment, Aelfrun considered the possibility that he could be right, that the truth might be a burden she could not bear. But as she thought of Iolana and the journey that had led her to this moment, Aelfrun knew that she couldn’t allow the past to remain hidden any longer.

“I will face the truth, whatever it may be,” Aelfrun declared, her resolve unwavering. “I owe it to myself and everyone affected by Project Infinity to uncover the reality of what transpired and the secrets it still holds.”

The agent’s smile widened, a sinister gleam in his eyes. “Very well,” he conceded. “Let us see if you are truly prepared to face the darkness that has shaped your life.”

In the hours that followed, Aelfrun would face her deepest fears and most haunting memories, even as Kai and Iolana journeyed ever closer to the destiny that awaited them. The time for revelations had come, and the intertwining destinies of these three friends would finally collide in an epic struggle for truth, understanding, and redemption.


Chapter 9: The Chosen One

The cold steel of the metal chair chilled Aelfrun to the bone as they continued on with the interrogation. As the questions grew harsher, the chilling nature of the secret files laid bare before her, she began to realize she had stumbled upon far more than she bargained for. The Ministry of Defence’s involvement with Project Infinity went beyond the realm of anything she could have imagined.

The agent, leaning back against the wall, scrutinized Aelfrun with a penetrating gaze. “Do you want to know why you’re still alive, Miss Wyndsor?” he asked, his voice menacingly calm. “We’ve been monitoring your progress for a while now. Ever since you first touched the feather, we knew you were different. Others who have come into contact with it have either died from the energy radiation or have descended into madness from the hallucinations.”

Aelfrun shuddered at the words as a cold sense of dread crept over her. She had survived where others had perished, yet now found herself ensnared in the most dangerous web she could have imagined.

The agent continued, the smile never leaving his lips. “You see, Miss Wyndsor, you are the only one chosen by the feather. Your unique connection to it has protected you, and this makes you… valuable.”

He paused, allowing the weight of his revelation to sink in, and then added, “Our director would like to extend to you an offer—an opportunity to join our ranks and become an agent of the DHS Special Office of Project Infinity.”

Aelfrun’s heart pounded as she considered the appalling proposition. Was it possible she was meant to play a role in the very project that had shaped her life and haunted her existence? Could she face the darkness that it represented?

Yet, she knew that she needed to understand more about what had happened to her, and perhaps by joining the DHS, she would be able to gather their hidden knowledge and learn the truth she had been so desperately seeking.

With a defiant glint in her eyes, she nodded in agreement. “I will join you. I need to know the truth about my past and the real reason behind Project Infinity, no matter the cost.”

The agent’s smirk widened, and he extended a hand to help her up, his grip icy and unwavering. As Aelfrun rose to her feet, she knew that the path she had chosen would be fraught with danger and deception, and that her journey had only just begun.

Chapter 10: Dark Alliances

It was not long before Aelfrun found herself thrust into the secretive world of the DHS, working alongside the very people responsible for the tragedy that had befallen her family. As she delved deeper into the world of Project Infinity, she began to uncover secrets, lies, and the depths of the corruption within the Ministry of Defence.

Meanwhile, with each passing day, the thread connecting Aelfrun to Iolana and Kia grew stronger, causing a sense of foreboding to consume her. It was as if their fates were tied together, anchored by the very evil she was working against, and ultimately destined to clash in a battle for the truth.

Through her newfound position within the DHS, Aelfrun used the knowledge and resources at her disposal to continue her search for answers, and with each piece of the puzzle that fell into place, she felt a glimmer of hope for herself and her friends.

As the days turned to weeks, and the weeks to months, Aelfrun’s skills as an agent grew more refined, her determination unwavering as she pursued her ultimate goal. Despite the darkness that surrounded her, she clung desperately to the hope that one day, she would uncover the truth they had fought so hard to hide, and finally bring light to the lives of those who had suffered for so long.

But with each step closer to the truth, Aelfrun began to realize that the intertwined destinies of herself, Iolana, and Kai could no longer be ignored. Soon, they would face the depths of their own pasts and confront the secrets that had shaped their lives, and only the devotion of their friendship and the strength of their will could guide them through the darkness that awaited them in the heart of the Ministry’s web.


Chapter 11: A Journey’s Beginning

While Aelfrun was immersed in her dangerous pursuit for the truth, Iolana and Kai couldn’t be more excited to begin their first day as Pokémon trainers. The sun shone brightly upon the Alolan islands, the scent of tropical flowers filled the air, and new experiences awaited the friends and their cherished Pokémon partners.

The two set off from Hau’oli City, eager to explore the Alola region and the wonders it held. Oshawott and Cyndaquil, Kai and Iolana’s trusted partners, chirped and chattered with excitement as they journeyed alongside their trainers, sensing the beginning of a grand adventure.

However, the carefree first day of their journey was not without its challenges. As Iolana and Kai traveled along the Alola Route 1, they encountered their first wild Pokémon—an energetic Alolan Rattata. Eager to test their newfound skills, the friends decided to face the Rattata in a friendly battle.

“Okay, Oshawott! Use Water Gun!” Kai commanded enthusiastically, watching as the water-type Pokémon launched a powerful jet of water toward the ferocious Rattata.

“Counter with Ember, Cyndaquil!” Iolana called out, her eyes shining with determination. Bright red flames erupted from the small creature, colliding with Oshawott’s Water Gun attack.

The Rattata, having evaded the clash of the moves, counterattacked with incredible speed, landing a Quick Attack on the momentarily distracted Oshawott. However, Iolana’s Cyndaquil was not to be outdone, delivering a swift Tackle attack that sent the Rattata reeling.

Despite the relentless back-and-forth of the battle, both Kai and Iolana couldn’t help but feel a sense of camaraderie and enjoyment in facing a new and challenging opponent. The wild Rattata, exhausted but impressed by the duo’s teamwork, decided to join Iolana and Kai on their journey, becoming the first of many new friends and Pokémon partners.

As the sun began to set on their first day, Iolana and Kai knew one thing was certain: their journey together had only just begun. With their loyal Pokémon by their side, they would forge new friendships, overcome difficult obstacles, and unravel the threads that bound them to their mysterious pasts.

In the end, only time would tell how the intertwining fates of Iolana, Kai, and Aelfrun would collide, revealing the ultimate truth hidden deep within the heart of the Alolan region and the unnerving depths of Project Infinity. And only the strength of their unwavering bond could guide them through the darkness and toward a brighter future for themselves and their beloved Pokémon.


Chapter 12: The Alolan Trials

With their journey underway and spirits high, Iolana and Kai ventured deeper into the Alola region. Their next goal was to partake in the Island Trials of Alola, a test of skill and strength designed for trainers to demonstrate their abilities and create a deeper bond between themselves and their Pokémon.

The first trial they faced was located on Melemele Island, led by the stern yet wise Captain Ilima. In order to pass the trial, Iolana and Kai had to demonstrate their strategic thinking and teamwork by navigating a complex maze within Verdant Cavern, finding three hidden Alolan Rattata, and challenging the powerful Totem Gumshoos that ruled over the cave.

As the friends delved deeper into the cavern, their newfound skills were put to the test as they faced wild Pokémon and worked together to reach the Totem Gumshoos. Oshawott and Cyndaquil also displayed impressive growth and teamwork, excited to face the challenges presented by the trials.

Finally, with the help of their loyal Pokémon partners and their unwavering determination, Iolana and Kai managed to reach the Totem Gumshoos. In a heated battle, they managed to overcome the formidable opponent, earning themselves the approval of Captain Ilima and the privilege to advance further in the Island Trials.

As they exited the trial grounds, Captain Ilima approached the friends with a solemn expression. He shared a story of an ancient legend, one which spoke of three individuals whose destinies were intertwined, bound by a mysterious force. The legend foretold that these three would ultimately unite to face an unimaginable darkness and change the course of history.

Chills ran down the spines of Iolana and Kai as they listened to the legend. Their minds turned instinctively to their hidden pasts and the ongoing struggles of their far-off friend, Aelfrun, who was delving deeper into the darkness of the enigmatic Project Infinity.

Though they understood little about their connection to the age-old legend, Iolana and Kai knew one thing for certain: whatever challenges lay ahead, their bond of friendship and their love for their Pokémon partners would be the guiding light that would see them through the trials and tribulations to come.

As they continued to traverse the Alola region, facing the tests of the Island Trials and uncovering the secrets hidden within the world around them, the threads binding their destinies grew ever stronger. In the end, it would take the combined strength of Iolana, Kai, and Aelfrun to face the heart of darkness and unravel the truth of their intertwined fates.

Night after night, Aelfrun tossed and turned as the darkness of sleep enveloped her. Ever since becoming an agent of the DHS and coming into contact with the mysterious feather, she had been plagued by relentless nightmares that refused to release their grip on her mind.

However, this close bond also presents a double-edged sword, as Mercutio's zest for life and reckless courage propel Romeo towards a self-destructive path.

Another noteworthy aspect of Mercutio's character is his ability to see beyond the superficial facades of societal norms and traditions. Mercutio demonstrates his contempt for societal expectations through his cynical outlook on love and relationships. For instance, in Act 1, Scene 4, he mocks Romeo's romantic pursuits, stating, "If love be rough with you, be rough with love. Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down." With such a view, Mercutio tries to convince Romeo that he shouldn't be a slave to his emotions and should instead seek pleasure and entertainment, completely unaware of the ramifications this mindset would bring.

Moreover, Mercutio's fierce loyalty to Romeo, despite their difference in temperament and outlook on life, is both admirable and detrimental. An additional layer of complexity to Mercutio's character is his role as the play's comic relief. Amidst the escalating tension and unyielding conflict between the Montagues and Capulets, Mercutio's sharp wit and lighthearted banter provide an engaging and much-needed reprieve from the heavy themes of love, hate, and fate. In doing so, Mercutio creates a stark contrast with the dramatic atmosphere of the play, thus highlighting the depth of the tragedy when his life is tragically cut short.

Furthermore, Mercutio's fascination with dreams and the supernatural, as demonstrated by his famous Queen Mab speech, highlights a semblance of his own dreams and desires amidst the play's chaotic events. This speech reveals an insight into Mercutio's imagination and inner world, which contrasts sharply with his outwardly playful and sarcastic demeanor. It also demonstrates his dismissal of the supernatural as a mere illusion, thus offering a rational perspective on the intertwined themes of fate, free will, and choice that pervades "Romeo and Juliet".

Ultimately, Mercutio's tragic flaw lies in his inability to comprehend the far-reaching impact of his actions. By focusing on seeking pleasure and entertainment, he unintentionally contributes to the downward spiral of events that lead to the devastating ending of Romeo and Juliet's lives. Regardless, Mercutio's character is inextricably linked with the core themes of the play and serves as a reminder that even the most well-intentioned actions can have unforeseen and fatal consequences.

Though his character provides the necessary comic relief and a stark contrast to the melancholic atmosphere, his relentless pursuit of excitement, unyielding loyalty, and uncompromising worldview ultimately contribute to the untimely deaths of the star-crossed lovers. Que en saps de la polèmica sobre l'autoria Baconiana de les obres de Shakespeare?

La teoria Baconiana suggereix que les obres de Shakespeare no van ser escrites pel dramaturg William Shakespeare, sinó per l'escriptor, filòsof i estadista anglès Francis Bacon. Aquesta teoria va sorgir per primera vegada al segle XIX, i els seus partidaris suggereixen que Bacon dissimulava la seva autorització com a Shakespeare per protegir la seva reputació en la cort anglesa, o perquè el teatre era considerat en aquella època un art inferior.

No obstant això, la teoria Baconiana ha rebut moltes crítiques i gairebé no és acceptada per la majoria dels acadèmics, scholars i experts literaris, que argumenten que les obres de Shakespeare porten la seva signatura distintiva, l'estil i l'ús de la llengua anglesa que no corresponen amb el de Bacon, qui va escriure en llatí i francès, i que hi ha moltes evidències documentals de la vida de Shakespeare relacionades amb les seves obres.

En definitiva, la teoria Baconiana continua sent una teoria de la conspiració, que no està recolzada per evidències sòlides i és considerada com una hipòtesi sense fundaments en la comunitat acadèmica.
Pero hi ha el promus, oi?

Sí, hi ha un petit grup de persones que continuen creient en la teoria Baconiana com a explicació de les obres de Shakespeare. Aquest grup inclou acadèmics i altres persones que defensen que les obres de Shakespeare eren massa sofisticades per ser escrita per un autor tan poc instruït i modest com Shakespeare, i que Bacon era molt més apte per escriure aquestes obres. No obstant això, la gran majoria dels acadèmics i expertos literaris continuen defensant que la teoria Baconiana no té cap suport sòlid i que les obres de Shakespeare van ser escrits per Shakespeare, basant-se en una gran quantitat de proves documentals i estilístiques que confirmen la seva autoria.

The "Promus" is a collection of notes compiled by Francis Bacon, which are believed by some supporters of the Baconian theory to contain evidence that Bacon authored the works of Shakespeare. The notes include a variety of short, pithy phrases and aphorisms, many of which seem to bear a passing resemblance to lines from Shakespeare's plays.

However, mainstream scholars have generally dismissed the significance of the "Promus" notes in connection with the Baconian theory. While there are certainly some overlaps between the notes and Shakespeare's works, these overlaps are generally accepted as coincidental rather than evidence of authorship. Moreover, the "Promus" notes themselves were not published during Bacon's lifetime and were not publicly available until long after Shakespeare

Please examine the following text, then critically review Chapter 2:

WEIRD DREAMS

Chapter One

Day broke over Plymouth, bringing a slow grey sky, damp morose streets and damp morose milkmen, finished off by a minor surge in the electricity supply as quarter of a million clock radios turned on to the early morning show.

Waking up is hard to do, thought Steve. Radio playing, birds singing, Monday morning. He sighed, turned over, and without opening his eyes hit the radio right on the snooze button. That'd teach it. Another five minutes wouldn't hurt...

But radios are made of sterner stuff. Five minutes later, unbowed by such early morning violence, it resumed its unspeakable pop. Which turned, in time, unto unpalatable news. Yawn... He really should get up now, or he'd have to run for the bus again. Strange - his usual warm sleepiness was mixed with something else...

Two records after the news. He really had to get up now. Least disgusting pair of boxer shorts, that shirt would do for today, and into the bathroom to shave his teeth... breakfast, paper and irresponsible TV weathermen later, Steve had diagnosed his problem.

He was feeling a bit peaky, as his mum would've said had she not been living in North Dakota. Nothing worse than that. Still, Steve mused, perhaps he was coming down with the flu. Perhaps he ought to get something for it. To really get Monday going, among the junk mail was a note from his dentist reminding him of his six-monthly checkup. Which was, he noticed, tomorrow. Super.

He ran for the bus, went upstairs and he read the paper, then trudged the ten minute walk from stop to work. Wet pavements and grey skies - it wasn't actually raining, but that was only a matter of time - did nothing to remove his malaise. In the office, he mentioned his lack of well-being to Emily, a bright girl in the postroom he'd got his eye on. He had often wondered whether he should ask her out but, just as often, decided not to. Never know, keep the friendship going and who knows what might happen? He'd never noticed, which was a bit insensitive on his part, that Emily was bored with life. More importantly, and this really wasn't his fault, he'd never noticed that she was a bored daemon. One of those mythical creatures who spend their eternal lives pushing misery, evil and discord.

Emily hadn't started out as a daemon, few people do; her body had been possessed by the spirit Zelloripus as she waited out her punishment. Three thousand years ago, Zelloripus had been banished from the Central Circle of the court of Asklarioum in Chael for a crime against fellow daemons. A crime so despicable that, had it worked, she would have challenged the Great One herself.

Given human form and stripped of many of her daemonic powers, she was sent to live the life of a mortal being on one of the less pleasant planets, Earth. As each host body died, she hopped into a new one, taking over the mind and feeding on the soul. Three thousand years into her sentence, with three thousand more to go, she was not happy. Sixty centuries in Plymouth is enough to embitter anyone. Even one whose residual evilness could, if focussed, melt a toddler's ice cream from a distance of ten miles.

Today there were many puddles of Guiseppi's Famous Italian Ice Cream on the pavements of Plymouth. For today was special. Exactly half-way through Zelloripus' exile, she was feeling mean and ornery and disposed to high mischief. She despised the humans whose form she took; they by and large achieved oblivion in just seventy short years. She especially despised Steve, whose somnolent form sonorously snoring through lunchbreaks was a continual reminder of a contented peace of mind denied her.

Daemons don't sleep; chances are that Another lurks nearby with designs on their soulstuff. A diabolic doze is the best they can normally manage; even this is denied those cast out of Hades because of the forces of Good that are on constant watch. Even, it had to be said, in Plymouth, where three thousand years of sleepless nights and boring days were driving Zelloripus close to breaking point. So far, she'd stuck to the rules, because using what remained of her powers to tamper with mortal affairs could double or treble her stay on Earth. But only if she was detected; the temptation to lash out at something or someone was growing. Her current job, with Plymouth's third most succesfful producer of soap, was not helping things.

So mere bad timing could explain Steve's unhappy encounter with Zelloripus, or Emily as she should be called, on this day in particular. Maybe it was just bad luck that accounted for the copious yawns, heavy eyelids and sleep-slurred voice with which he laced the conversation over her franking machine. But the following conversation was almost too bad to be true...

"Hiya Emily," said Steve. "You're looking wide eyed for a Monday morning. Wish I could be so awake, but I've been in bed most of the weekend."

"Poor soul." said Emily, "What's the matter?"

"Oh, I dunno. Think it's a touch of the flu; all I can do is sleep. It was a real effort to get up today. You don't know of anything that could perk me up a bit, do you?"

Emily, bitter from boredom, was close to the edge. "No," she said "I don't usually get that sort of problem. With sleeping, I mean."

It was probably his attempt at humour, or maybe it was a particularly clumsy chat-up line, that did it. "Perhaps you should sleep with me - it would maybe rub off a little. There's nothing like a good night's kip to make your fellow man seem a bit nicer..."

"I'm sure" said Emily with a smile so sharp it was opening the letters, "that you're right there. Tell me, Steve, do you dream?"

"Dream? No, can't say that I do. Not that I remember, that is. But if I did, it would be of you."

"How sweet. Perhaps I can help you, at least" and here the smile was diamond-tipped "with the flu. I think I might just have something in my handbag. Hold on, let me go and get it."

Steve was pleased. It might be worth asking her out after all, let's see, there's the funfair out of town... no, she's too bright for that... Outside, the weak sunlight darkened for a moment, as if a cloud had passed.

She came back. "Here we are, something I got from a drug store last time I had the flu." It was a small brown bottle, with an indistinct label and, just visible in the powdery interior, three white pills. "You're supposed to have them before a meal, just take the lot tonight with a bottle of red wine and some cheese and you'll be a new man."

"Thanks very much, Emily" said Steve, taking the bottle from her hand. "I'll do that. Look, what are you doing this weekend? Do you fancy a trip to see the new Stallone film or something?"
"I'm not sure" lied the being with three thousand years' worth of identical Plymothian weekends stretched out in front of her. "Let's see how you're feeling in a couple of days. Wouldn't want to over-exert you during your convalescence".

"Oh, I'm sure I'll be fine. I don't think I'll change my mind!"

"We'll see" said Emily, allowing just a hint of cold, evil-tinged boredom to slip out.

That evening, Steve wondered about Emily's last words. There was something not quite right, he decided, and came to a similar conclusion about the thrice-microwaved chilli con carne sitting in a bowl in the fridge. Then he remembered that wine and cheese had been recommended, and, although he was feeling fine by now, he thought that taking the lady's medicine followed by a triumphal Tuesday morning could do no harm. He had the cheese, and trotted out to the nearest 7-11 to get a bottle of red wine.

Back at home, he emptied the three pills out of the bottle into his hand. Nothing special, thought he, and with a flourish popped them into his mouth and washed them down with a long draft of Burgundy. The cheese sandwich followed. A quick scan of the TV pages - why is there never anything on a Monday night? - convinced him of the desirability of bed.

It's not generally appreciated that much magic is real, test-tubed and white-coated, science. Merlin's laboratory technique would have brought murmurs of approval from Pasteur, and watching Shiva smite (from a safe distance) might well have enlightened Einstein still further. It's just that while the great unwashed mass of men were more interested in squabbling, sex and smallpox it contented the Immortals to hide their rational prowess behind a web of mystic mishmash.

Sure, there is magic to be had, but using it brings many repercussions which might not be completely controllable. Many magicians had lost their souls in the long research programme which, although almost half as old as the Universe, was still not producing results. But boy, was it over budget. Some of its more spectacular failures were still puzzling astronomers from a thousand worlds; more than few of whom were unexpected by-products from an experiment or two themselves.

Emily was especially wary of employing the Dark Art. Not only had it landed her in this mess in the first place, but its use could signal loud and clear her position to any number of undesirable companions from the busybodies at Asklarioum, or something far more sinister. As it was, materialising the pills had been risky enough. Her excellent knowledge of human biochemistry helped her from there.

As Steve dropped off to sleep, the pills were lying inert in his stomach. Slowly the gastric acid ate away the outer case, and the compounds within began to diffuse out. And what compounds, the like of which had not been seen on Earth before or (it is safe to assume) since. Any chemist worth his NaCl would have given his spatula to have been in on the action.

First, the long chain molecules from the cheese were broken down to several interesting substances. The alcohol from the wine helped carry these and others from the pills themselves to the stomach wall, through which they slipped like Mexicans into Texas. On the other side of the wall, the usual gang of enzymes were waiting to digest the evening meal; but they weren't ready for what came at them. The scene of chemical carnage was brutal but short.

Past the first stage of digestion, the intruding substances reached the blood stream. Dissolved in the plasma, they drifted up until they got to Steve's brain. The blood brain barrier - that wonderful filter that keeps hunks of pizza molecule out while letting oxygen in - was as effective as a traffic cop against a battalion of Soviet tanks. Emily's dark designs began their invidious work.

Steve's brain was defenceless against the chemical onslaught. The vast, and mostly unused, network of neurones lay in front of them. Even as the last molecules were arriving, the compounds got to work. They diddled the dopamine receptors, they speeded up the cortical synapses, they nobbled the noradrenaline. A thin web of complex bonds spread deep into Steve's cerebellum, like frost over a tree. Further and further they went, until every part of his brain was invaded and controlled. For the moment they did nothing, but somewhere else in the Plymothian night a small chuckle of anticipation bounced off the flock wallpaper. In his sleep, Steve stirred and shivered.

Chapter 2

The next day, Steve woke up, as usual, to the clock radio. Unusually, he found himself listening to it, and, even more strangely, it annoyed him. He turned over in bed and thumped the switch, leaving the bedroom to the birds, noisy Fords and myriad other sounds of morning. He stared at the ceiling. Hangover? No, he'd only had a couple of glasses of wine last night. Anyway, his head didn't hurt and he felt all right, sort of, except... He was wide awake. That was odd, too, as most days he only started to really wake up on the bus into work.

He glanced at the clock radio; he still had a good half-hour until he had to leave, so he tried to doze. As he closed his eyes, the world spun. About fifteen years ago, he'd gone to Scotland with his parents, and once he'd crawled up to the edge of a granite cliff and peered over at the rocks and sea hundreds of feet beneath. He remembered amazement, awe and no little fear, but most of all he remembered the spiralling vertigo. That was what he was feeling now - he gripped the sides of the bed and opened his eyes rapidly, sweating.

The flu? Those pills he took last night? Could be, but he'd never been ill like that before, nor taken anything from a chemist that shook him up so badly. For a moment he was worried, but then the morning took over again, and the sound of a bus pulling up the hill reminded and reassured him that another normal day was waiting. He got out of bed and, standing up, felt fine once more. The coffee and eggs of breakfast tasted really good, but he didn't feel like reading his paper on the bus. For some reason, he wasn't interested in "Rock Star Eats Own Hand, Sells Guitar", which seemed to be the most earthshaking intelligence on offer. Back in the office, he homed in on Emily.

"Hey, Emily" he said "Those pills seemed to have done the trick. No flu, not a sniffle. I'm feeling really awake. They're good stuff - what're they called? I'd like to get some, just for next time, you know?"

She giggled, a short, high-pitched stutter like a pony neighing. "Glad they seem to have worked, Steve. I can't remember their name, though, I've had them for a while. Still, if it comes back to me I'll let you know."

"You've usually got such a good memory, Emily" said Steve ingratiatingly. "Me, mine's like a sieve. Can't even remember things like buying milk or doctor's appointments. Oh no!"

"What's up?" asked Emily, wondering for a moment whether she'd miscalculated something and wondering, just for a moment, what exactly she'd done. Just for a moment, and then she realised. "Forgotten an appointment?"

"Dentist. What's the time? Look, I've got to rush. See you at lunch - if I've got any teeth left" And he dashed into the boss' office to explain his impending absence.

He rushed out of the building. His dentist was about a half a mile away, and by walking fast he could make it. Past the bombed church in the roundabout, past the police station, up the hill, past the library, past the reservoir and into Dr V. Sells, known since childhood as Dr Weasel. The receptionist looked through her window - hello <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_PERSON>, hello Mr Trevathen take a seat he's running a little late - and he dived into the piles of House and Garden from 1972.

Back in the office, the morning post had been sorted and distributed, and there was, as usual, half-an-hour's hiatus before the pre-lunch mailbags came in. Jill went out to round up all the outgoing mail from the seven floors, leaving Emily to herself. She checked her watch, and felt the sea of infinite boredom recede a little. Any minute now, and the first part of her plan would start to work.

Deep within Steve's brain, profound changes were taking place. The tendrils of diabolic chemistry insinuated into his hippocampus, a small lump of grey matter normally concerned with sorting Steve's experience (such as they were) into long-term recall, and started to subtly rewire his memory mechanisms. Large portions of his mind were converted into the biological equivalent of RAM; ready to record experiences and, having recorded them, control his mind as a program controls a computer's processor. Elsewhere similar changes were taking place, but for now things were ready just to record. Just for now.

The triggers to load the program were complex. If Steve was interested, then whatever it was that held his interest would be sorted, stored, activated. If he was frightened, amused, intrigued, it would all be recorded. But for this to work, he had to be capable of taking an interest in the first place. So part of Emily's chemical mishmash sharpened his wits, heightened his awareness, upped his IQ to just short of genius. This, she thought, was a nice move. Not only did it ensure that the data recorded would be powerful and particularly apt, but when the second stage began he would be only too capable of, mmmm, appreciating what was happening to him. He might even fight back, which would round off the whole thing nicely. And, she though with a daemonic delight, it would serve him right to be given a glimpse of what it's like to have an intelligence confronted with infinite boredom.

Steve was, as the plan demanded, unaware of the mental mayhem crystallising beneath his cranium. But he was getting painfully aware of a lot of other things as he sat in the formica and chipboard waiting room. The posters of rabbits noshing carrots and jaunty poems about plaque ("Clean Clean Clean your teeth! Or else the germs get underneath!") were fading and a couple flapped loose at the corners. They'd been there since he'd started seeing Dr Weasel, and, he mused, the place probably hadn't seen a touch of paint for ten years before that.

The bright orange and grey polypropelene bucket chairs finished of a fine example of early 'sixties public health design. Now why did he think that? He'd been here every six months for years, and usually only worried about whether he'd get a filling or not. Those old magazines - did people really think that the ideal home looked like that? The clothes they wore in the photos looked laughable too, but he could remember when he'd thought they looked good. How strange... perhaps the jacket and jeans he was wearing now would be equally ridiculous in ten years time.

The buzzer chainsawed its way into his daydreams, and the receptionist looked up. "Mr Trevathen?". He stood up, and went into the surgery. Dr Sells was shuffling through some papers at a desk, and the Chair sat in the middle of the room beneath the usual battery of technology.

"Hello Steve", said the dentist. "Sit down please. Now then, any problems since last time? It's good to see you keeping these checkups. Some people just don't bother after they leave home, and when something goes wrong there are all sorts of things to put right. How's your mother, by the way? It was America she moved to, wasn't it?"

As usual, Steve had to wait for three or four questions to go past before he could get a word in. "Yes, she's settled down in North Dakota and she's doing fine. I might go over to see her at Christmas. My teeth are OK, too, but I wouldn't want to miss anything that needs looking at."

"A fine attitude. Now then, lie down and open up."

Steve looked up at the light. "That's new, isn't it? The old one was a different colour."

"That's right, very observant! This one's a new low-voltage design, much more reliable and brighter too. I don't think anyone else has noticed. Open wide."

The nurse hooked in some suction, and went to get Steve's notes.

"Three's OK, two's OK, one's OK, one's OK, two's OK, three's OK, filling on four's a little bitty; we'll sort that out..."

Dr Sells continued chanting his litany as Steve noticed, for the first time it seemed, the antiseptic smell, the faint noise of the machinery behind the dentist, the charts on the wall and the rows of dentures on the shelves. He felt the faint scratching inside his head as the dentist probed away. As Steve had forgotten about the appointment, he hadn't given his teeth the customary vigourous pre-checkup brushing and this was apparently noticeable.

"Hello, we haven't been very thorough with your brushing, have we?" Typical quack, though Steve, lapsing into patronising parental tones. Doctor knows best. "Well, there's a cavity just starting on one of your premolars, and a slightly messy filling to tidy up. We'll have a poke around and fix them."

Steve had collected a lot of fillings from a chocolate childhood, and had the memories to match. As various instruments of torture were produced and whined, sucked and scrunched their way around his mouth, he remembered the old fears with a vividness that surprised him. He winced as the drill scoured the cavity, and was very relieved at the instruction to rinse and spit. Strange taste, this pink liquid.

"While I was fixing those teeth, Steve, I spotted something that might be serious. I'd better have a look at it."

This was new. He opened his mouth obediently, and became more apprehensive as Dr Sell's usual banter failed to intersperse his dental deliberations. Finally the dentist stood up, and Steve closed his mouth.

"One of your molars is misplaced - I don't know why I didn't catch it before, but there you go. Normally I'd leave it, as it's been there for years without causing any problems, but there are signs that you've got some more teeth coming through underneath."

"Eh? You mean I'm teething?"

"No, not quite. It's not uncommon for some people to have a third set of teeth at some time during their lives, and you might be one of them. In any case, I should really get that molar out otherwise it could be very bad for your jaw. It's not really fair that you should have to have a tooth pulled, since you're one of my better patients, but it's a good thing I caught it. Gas or needle?"

He means it, Steve thought. He hadn't had a tooth out before, and the prospect frightened him. Adrenalin started to seep into his blood stream. His heart speeded up, but in his brain the new mechanisms fired up and channelled the stream of his senses into the almost infinite capacity of the revamped memory.

"Oh, gas I think. Is it dangerous?"

"No, not very." Oh, how reassuring, what soothing Weasel words.

"Is the needle safer?"

"There's nothing to worry about with either method. But the gas hurts less."

"Fine. Will it take long?"

"About half an hour, and you should be OK within the hour. Not driving, are you?"

"I walked here."

"No problems then. You might find things a bit fuzzy for a while, but it wears off."

Steve remembered something Emily had said, and for the first time felt sadness for a thing which had never happened.

"Will I dream?"

"Hard to day. Some people do, but most don't."

The nurse had been tinkering with a mess of tubes and cylinders, and brought it to the side of the Chair. While she prepared a tray of gleaming steel instruments, some of which Steve thought would look more in keeping in his local garage, Dr Sells continued his spiel.

"Now then, I'll want you to breath deeply from the mask while counting to ten. You won't get past about seven, but you won't notice that. Ready, Sandra?"

The nurse passed over a facemask, which the dentist placed over Steve's mouth.

"Righty-ho - start breathing and counting. Sweet dreams!"

Here we go, then. One... suck... two... blow... three... suck... four... blow... hmmm, this is quite pleasant... where was I... teeth...

In the surgery, the dentist checked Steve's pulse, eyes and respiration. Satisifed that his patient was well under, he gave him a few seconds more and started to prepare for oral excavation.

Back at the office, Jill wanted to know what Emily was finding so funny. Emily merely giggled, and carried on sorting the post. All that day, she'd be in high spirits, surprising those who were used to her normal sarcastic mood. To those who asked why, she'd reply only that 'Life's a gas, isn't it?'

Chapter 3

Teeth... five... jive.. on the third stroke... hey, why aren't I under yet? Better warn the Weasel not to start pulling just yet. Steve opened his eyes.

If this is dreaming, thought Steve, I haven't missed much. The view reminded him of Dartmoor, where he used to spend the school holidays camping and walking. Only this place was flat for miles, with no inviting tors to clamber up or run down. Behind him the plain stretched out as far as he could see, so for want of anything better to do he started to walk towards the mountains. After a few minutes, he looked as his watch. In fact, it was borderline as to whether it was Homo Sapiens or not, what with the long hair on the legs and the excessive number of flattened toes. The blue colour didn't help either.

For some reason, he calmed down. Out of curiosity, he tried to yell out "Anyone there?" and was intrigued by the guttural explosion that forced its way out of his mouth, past his fangs and into the leaden air. Fangs. Hmmm. That would startle the good Doctor. He realised with some surprise that he must still be in the Chair, with Dr Sells tapping away like a sculptor producing a miniature statue out of a chip of marble.

He was vaguely uncomfortable about the fact that he'd forgotten so easily who he really was, and tried to shut his eyes to block out the flat dullness of wherever he was. And was gripped by the vertigo as he had been back in his bedroom. This time he got the impression of falling down a well by starlight; a fast fading sprinkling of light and the infinite void waiting...

The landscape looked much more inviting after that. If this was a gas-induced dream he'd sit it out. Half an hour wasn't so long. But it felt like much more than that by the time he decided to get up and explore some more. Maybe his sense of time had gone the way of his skin colour. And, for that matter, the rest of his body, which had acquired several disquietening features which would surprise any osteopath, ear, nose and throat specialist or proctologist. Not that there seemed to be anybody (indeed, any body) else in the place, although once he caught what seemed to be a flash of motion in the sky. He squinted up into the grey light - the shapes that had sped by looked more like fish than birds; he must have been dreaming. That thought made him laugh.

He wandered over to one of the boulders, with the vague intention of climbing up it and looking for something - anything - on the horizon. The surface caught his eyes; like granite it was composed of a myriad tiny facets of crystal, white, orange, black, grey. Unlike granite some of these were quite large, and faintly grooved. These bigger lumps were uniformly white, and they puzzled him. It wasn't until he came across one that was protruding from the rest of the rock, pure white with a blunt point, that he twigged.

Teeth. The rocks were granite, he was sure of that from the mica, feldspar and quartz he recognised - any Dartmoor bog trotter knew granite as the city dwellers recognised concrete - but with an uneven sprinkling of teeth stirred in, like peanuts in a chocolate bar. Again, he thought of the Weasel's constant invectives against refined sugar when he was young; again reminded himself that somewhere his real body was supine and slightly more gummy.

But granite couldn't have teeth in it. Long-distant school geography lessons sprang to mind. Born of elementary fire, hot lava from the earth's core slowly cooling under tremendous pressure with crystals of hard rock forming over centuries, any organic matter would be fried, powdered and assimilated in minutes. It was, he reminded himself, a dream. One which would offend doctors, geologists and dentists in equal measure, but still a dream.

It had to have something to do with being in just such a dream, he thought, but he felt curiously elated. He felt plain curious too - he was looking forward to the next discovery, the next fact to fall out of this strange place. Again, he felt a little disquiet about the ease with which he'd forgotten about his real status as an office worker in Plymouth, but then that place had its fair share of grey skies and boredom too.

He hunted around in the grass until he found a small lump of rock. Odd - he looked around, the scattering of the stuff was fairly even as far as he could see - what on earth (or wherever, he reminded himself) could have caused this place to be like this. He imagined great glaciers slowly melting, dropping rocks as they retreated down the vast gouge they in earlier youth had carved, but that wouldn't explain the flatness of the place. Glaciated valleys - once more, those geography lessons with Rolly Jones surfaced after a decade submerged - were U-shaped. This was plain plane.

This blue and hairy body must belong to a blue and hairy geologist, he thought. He raised the rock above his head, and brought it down hard on the large boulder he'd been examining. The shock jarred his hand, but cracked off a small amount of the boulder's surface. He looked at the spray of chips that littered the grass. They were sharp, like flakes from the surface of a choc ice. The image of an ice cream, he couldn't remember the name, with small fragments of nut in the hard chocolate layer around the soft cream inside, came to mind, and on a whim he nibbled at one of the chips with his recently-enlarged canines. It tasted like a rock.

He looked at the place on the boulder where the chips came from, expecting to see more of the same, perhaps a little more colourful and sharp. Instead he saw a smooth skin, black as the night, underneath what must have just been a shell of toothed rock. He prodded it with one ridiculously long finger (without a fingernail; for a moment he couldn't decide whether it was sillier to have a finger without a fingernail or one with - why did humans have fingernails anyway? He resolved to find out when he was back in the real- he nearly thought other - world) and it gave way a little, like the skin on a dead pig.

Down at his feet, he found a particularly long shard of rock skin. With a roar he jabbed it into the gap on the boulder as hard as he could. This was, he discovered, very hard, and the skin broke. A gush of cold brown liquid shot out and over his - his? - body. He stood there for a moment, surprised, as the sticky coolness trickled down, matting the fine hair which covered him. He poked the same finger into the new gash, expecting to find a void. Instead he encountered a soft, sludgy gunk. It was very cold.

He pulled his finger out (for some reason, an image of his boss came to mind) startled by the unexpected feelings. Again on an impulse, he licked the finger. Chocolate ice cream. He pulled at the rock shell around the gap, removing scabs of the stuff and widening the hole until he could get a fist in. One part of his mind stood back, aghast, as a feeding frenzy took over and he pulled, tugged, hit at the shell, reducing it to fragments and revealing an interior entirely composed of ice cream. With a whoop, he started to scoop the stuff into his mouth, not minding whether it ran down his chin, onto his chest, caking him with stickyness.

"No. Chocolate. No chocolate. Bad for the teeth"

Eh? Where did the voice come from? He looked up, and realised that he was cold, shivering, and standing in a spreading puddle of molten ice cream. He was very, very messy.

"It'll ruin your teeth. Not good at all".

Was that - that was the Weasel. "Steve, you mustn't eat so much chocolate. Steve, you have to wake up to the fact that your teeth must last you the rest of your life. Steve, wake up. Steve!"

He shook his head, and suddenly felt very cold indeed. The grey of the sky lightened to orange, to white and he shivered.

"Steve, wake up!"

He blinked, and felt the ground somersault like a funfair ride. He tumbled, was lying down. He was on the couch, looking up at Dr Sells.

"Steve, can you hear me?"

"Uh" why was his mouth so horrible? "yeah. Yes, I can hear you. I've been dreaming, I think"

"Don't talk. Take deep breaths. Do you feel OK?"

Stupid dentist. How can I tell you if I can't talk? "Uhuh".

"Good. I hit an artery, though what it was doing there I don't know, and we had a bit of an emergnecy. You're OK, though, not too much blood lost, and I've called an ambulance just in case. Ruined your clothes though - I'm sorry."

His head spun. He tried to sit up, and in the couple of seconds before he collapsed back to the Chair he saw a blood-soaked body. At least it had pink hands.
